hymns.title: HYMN I. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: I Laud Agni, the chosen Rsi, Deva, the hotar, lavishest of wealth.

p: Worthy is Agni to be praised by living as by ancient seers. He shall bring hitherward the Devas.

p: Through Agni man obtaineth wealth, yea, most rich in heroes, glorious.

p: Agni, which thou encompassest about verily goeth to the Devas.

p: May Agni, open-minded Sage, truthful, most gloriously great, the Deva, come hither with the Devas.

p: Whatever blessing, Agni  Angiras, is indeed thy truth.

p: To thee, O Agni, day by day with meditation bringing thee reverence, we come

p: Lord of offerings, guard of Law Eternal, radiant One, increasing in thine own abode.

p: Be to us easy of approach, even as a father to his son: Agni, be with us for our weal.

hymns.title: HYMN II. Vayu.
hymns.text:
p: BEAUTIFUL Vayu, come, hear our call.

p: Knowing the days, the singers glorify thee, Vayu, with their hymns of praise.

p: Vayu, thy penetrating stream goes forth unto the worshipper, far-reaching.

p: These, indra and Vayu, we invite you to our offeirngs. The drops are yearning for you both.

p: Well do ye mark libations, ye Vayu and Indra, rich in spoil! So come ye swiftly hitherward.

p: Vayu and Indra, come to what we hath prepared, Heroes, thus we make our meditation.

p: We call, and foe subduing Varuna, who make the oil-fed rite complete.

p: Mitra and Varuna, through Law, lovers and cherishers of Law.

p: Our Sages, Mitra and Varuna, wide dominion, strong by birth, vouchsafe us strength that worketh well.

hymns.title: HYMN III. Asvins
hymns.text:
p: YE Asvins, rich in treasure. having nimble hands, accept the sacred food.

p: Ye Asvins, rich in wondrous deeds, heroes worthy of our offerings, accept our songs with mighty thought.

p: Nasatyas, wonder-workers, yours are these libations with clipt grass: Come ye whose paths are red with flame.

p: O Indra marvellously bright, come, these libations long for thee, thus by fine fingers purified.

p: Urged by the holy singer, sped by song, come, indra, to the meditation.

p: Approach, O Indra, hasting thee, Lord of Bay Horses, to the meditation. In our libation take delight.

p: Ye Devas, who protect, reward, and cherish men, approach your worshipper's drink-offering.

p: Ye Devas, swift at work, come hither quickly to the draught.

p: The Devas, accept the sacred draught.

p: Wealthy in spoil, enriched with hymns, with eager love,  'our offering.

p: Inciter of all pleasant songs, inspirer of all gracious thought, Indu accept our offering

p: Sarasvati, the mighty flood, she with her light illuminates, she brightens every pious thought.

hymns.title: HYMN IV. Indra
hymns.text:
p: We call the doer of fair deeds, to our assistance day by day.

p: Come thou to our libations! The rich One's rapture giveth kine.

p: May we be acquainted with thine innermost benevolence.

p: Go to the wise unconquered One, ask thou of Indra, skilled in song, him who is better than thy friends.

p: Whether the men who mock us say, Depart unto another place, Ye who serve Indra and non else;

p: Or whether, Deva.of wondrous deeds, all our true people call us blest. Still, may we dwell in Indra's care.

p: Unto the swift One bring the swift, man-cheering, grace of offering, that to the Friend gives wings and joy.

p: Thou helpest the warrior in the fray.

p: We strengthen, thee the powerful, Indra, we may win us wealth.

p: To him the mighty stream of wealth, prompt friend of him, to this Indra sing your song.

hymns.title: HYMN V. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: O Indra, sit ye down, Indra sing your song, companions, bringing hymns of praise.

p: To him the richest of the rich, the Lord of treasure.s excellent, indra, with Soma.

p: May he stand by us in our need and in abundance for our wealth: May he come nigh us with his strength.

p: To him, to Indra sing your song.

p: For his enjoyment, these pure drops.

p: Thou, grown at once to perfect strength, was born together with Soma, Strong Indra, for preëminence.

p: O Indra, lover of the song, may they bring bliss to thee the Sage.

p: Our chants of praise have strengthened thee, O Satakratu, and our praises. So strengthen thee the songs we sing.

p: Indra, accept these offerings thousandfoldwherein all manly powers abide.

p: O Indra, thou who lovest song.

hymns.title: HYMN VI. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: They who stand round him as he moves harness the bright, the ruddy  Steed. The lights are shining in the sky.

p: On both sides to the car they yoke the two bay coursers dear to him, Bold, tawny, bearers of the Chief.

p: Thou, making light where no light was, and form where form was not, was born together with the Dawns.

p: Thereafter they, as is their wont, threw off the state of babes unborn.

p: Thou, indra, with the Tempest-Devas, found the kine even in the cave.

p: Worshipping even as they list, singers laud him who findeth wealth, the far-renowned, the mighty One.

p: Mayest thou verily be seen coming by fearless Indra's side, both joyous, equal in your sheen.

p: With Indra's well beloved hosts, hastening to heaven.

p: Come from this place, O Wanderer, or downward from the light of heaven: Our songs of praise all yearn for this.

p: Indra we seek to give us help, from here, from heaven above the earth, or from the spacious firmament.

hymns.title: HYMN VII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: INDRA the singers with high praise, indra reciters with their lauds, indra the choirs have glorified.

p: Indra hath ever close to him his two bay steeds and word-yoked car, indra the golden, thunder-armed.

p: Indra hath raised the Sun on high in heaven, that h. May see afar.

p: Help us, O Indra, in the frays, yea, frays, where thousand spoils are gained.

p: We invoke Indra, indra, the Friend who listens.

p: Our manly Hero, thou forever bounteous, yonder cloud, for us, thou irresistible.

p: Still higher, thunder-armed Indra's praises rise, we find every song worthy of him.

p: He drives the people with his might, the Deva irresistible.

p: Indra who rules with single sway men, riches, and the fivefold race of those who dwell upon the earth.

p: From each side we call Indra away from other men: Ours, and none others’. May he be.

hymns.title: HYMN VIII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: INDRA, bring wealth that gives delight, the victor's ever-conquering wealth, most excellent, to be our aid;

p: By means of which we may repel our foes in battle hand to hand, by thee assisted with the car.

p: Aided by thee, the thunder-armed, indra, may we lift up the bolt, and conquer all our foes in fight.

p: With thee, O India, for ally with heroes. May we conquer our embattled foes.

p: Mighty is Indra, yea supreme; greatness be his, the Thunderer: Wide as the heaven extends his power

p: Which aideth those to win them sons, who come as heroes to the fight, or singers loving holy thoughts.

p: His belly, drinking deepest draughts of Soma, like an ocean swellslike wide streams from the cope of heaven.

p: So also is his excellence, great, vigorous, rich in wealth, like a ripe branch to the worshipper.

p: For verily thy mighty powers, indra, are saving helps at once unto a worshipper like me.

p: So are his lovely gifts; let lauds and praises be to Indra sung, that h. May drink the Soma juice.

hymns.title: HYMN IX. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: COME, indra, and delight thee at all the Deva banquets, protector, mighty in thy strength.

p: To Indra the gladdening, omnific Deity.

p: O Lord of all men, fair of cheek, rejoice thee in the gladdening laudspresent at these water-offerings.

p: Songs have outpoured themselves to thee, indra, the strong, the guardian Lord, and raised themselves unsatisfied.

p: Send to us bounty manifold, O Indra, worthy of our wish, for power supreme is only thine.

p: O Indra, O most splendid One.

p: Give, indra, wide and lofty fame, wealthy in strength, lasting our life-time.

p: Grant us high fame, O Indra, grant riches, those fair fruits of earth borne home in wains.

p: Praising with songs, we call Indra, the Treasure-Lord of wealth.

p: To lofty Indra, dweller by each libation, the pious man sings forth aloud a strengthening hymn.

hymns.title: HYMN X. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: THE chanters hymn thee, they who say the word of praise magnify thee. The Monks have raised thee up on high, O Satakratu, like a pole.

p: As up he clomb from ridge to ridge and looked upon the toilsome task, indra observes this wish of his, and the Rain hastens with his troop.

p: Harness thy pair of strong bay steeds, long-maned, whose bodies fill the girths, and, indra, Soma-drinker, come to listen to our songs of praise.

p: Come hither, answer thou the song, sing in approval, cry aloud. Good Indra, make our meditation succeed, and prosper this  'our offering.

p: To Indra must a laud be said, to strengthen him who freely gives, that Sakr. May take pleasure in our friendship and water-offerings.

p: Him, him we seek for friendship, him for riches and heroic might. For Indra, he is Sakra, he shall aid us while he gives us wealth.

p: Easy to turn and drive away, indra, is spoil bestowed by thee. Unclose the stable of the kine, and give us wealth O Thunder-armed

p: The heaven and earth contain thee not, together, in thy wrathful mood. Win us the waters of the sky, and send us kine abundantly.

p: Hear, thou whose ear is quick, my call; take to thee readily my songs O Indra, let this laud of mine come nearer even than thy friend.

p: We know thee mightiest of all. Of thee most mighty we invoke the aid that giveth thousandfold.

p: O Indra, enjoy our offering with delight. Prolong our life anew, and cause the seer to win a thousand gifts.

p: Lover of song. May these our songs on every side encompass thee: Strengthening thee of lengthened life. May they be dear delights to thee.

hymns.title: HYMN XI. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: ALL sacred songs have magnified Indra expansive as the sea, the best of warriors borne on cars, the Lord, the very Lord of strength.

p: Strong in thy friendship, indra, Lord of power and might, we have no fear. We glorify with praises thee.

p: The gifts of Indra from of old, when to the praise-singers he gives the boon of substance rich in kine.

p: The young, the wise, of strength unmeasured, was he born Sustainer of each sacred rite, indra, the Thunderer, much-extolled.

p: Lord of the thunder. 

p: I. Hero, through thy bounties am come to the flood addressing thee. Song-lover, here the singers stand and testify to thee thereof.

p: Indra! thou o’erthrewest with thy wondrous powers. The wise beheld this deed of thine: now go beyond their eulogies.

p: Our songs of praise have glorified Indra who ruleth by his might, whose precious gifts in thousands come, yea, even more abundantly.

hymns.title: HYMN XII. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: WE choose Agni the messenger, the herald, master of all wealth, well skilled in this  'our offering.

p: With callings ever they invoke Agni, Agni, Lord of the House, Oblation-bearer, much beloved.

p: Bring the Devas hither, Agni, born for him who strews the sacred grass: Thou art our herald, meet for praise.

p: Wake up the willing Devas, since thou, Agni, performest embassage: Sit on the sacred grass with Devas.

p: O Agni, radiant One, to whom the holy oil is poured, burn  'up our enemies whom fiends protect.

p: By Agni Agni is inflamed, Lord of the House, wise, young, who bears the gift.

p: Praise Agni in  'the offering, the Sage whose ways are ever true, the Deva who driveth grief away.

p: Deva, Agni, be his strong defence who lord of sacred giftsworshippeth thee the messenger.

p: Whoso with sacred gift would fain call Agni to the feast of Devas, O Purifier, favour him.

p: Such, Agni, purifier, bright, bring hither to  'our offering, to our oblation bring the Devas.

p: So lauded by our newest song of praise bring opulence to us, and food, with heroes for our sons.

p: O Agni, by effulgent flame, by all invokings of the Devas, show pleasure in this laud of ours.

hymns.title: HYMN XIII. Agni
hymns.text:
p: AGNI, well-kindled, bring the Devas for him who offers holy gifts. Worship them, purifier, Monk.

p: Son of Thyself, present, O Sage,  'our offering to the Devas today. Sweet to the taste, that the, may feast.

p: Dear Narasamsa, sweet of tongue, the giver of oblations, I Invoke to this  'our offering.

p: Agni, on thy most easy car, glorified, hither bring the Devas.

p: Strew, O ye wise, the sacred grass that drips with oil, in order due, Where the Immortal is beheld.

p: Thrown open be the Doors Divine, for offering this day and now.

p: I call, to seat them on the holy grass, at this our solemn offering.

p: I invite, the wise, divine and sweet of tongue, to celebrate this  'our offering.

p: Ila, Sarasvati, Mahi, three Devas who bring delight, be seated, peaceful, on the grass.

p: Tvastar I call, the earliest born, may he be ours and ours alone.

p: Deva, sovran of the Wood, present this our oblation to the Devas, and let the giver be renowned.

p: Pay  'the offering to Indra in the offerer's house: We call the Devas.

hymns.title: HYMN XIV, Devas.
hymns.text:
p: Soma, Agni, come, to our service and our songs. With all these Devas.

p: The Kanvas have invoked thee; they, O Singer, sing thee songs of praise Agni, come hither with the Devas;

p: Indra, Vayu, Narasamsa, Mitra, Agni, pusan, Bhaga, Adityas, and the Marut host.

p: For you these offerings are poured forth that gladden and exhilarate, the meath-drops resting in the cup.

p: Having strewn the grass, with offerings and all things prepared.

p: Let the swift steeds who carry thee, thought-yoked and dropping holy oil. Bring the DevasH.

p: Adored, the strengtheners of Law, unite them, Agni, O bright of tongue.

p: Let them, O Agni, who deserve worship and prase solemn offering.

p: Away, from the Sun's realm of light, the wise invoking Sage shall bring All Devas awaking with the dawn.

p: With all the Devas, with Indra, with Vayu, and Mitra's splendours, drink, Agni, Soma.

p: Hallow thou this  'our offering.

p: Harness the Red Mares to thy car, the Bays, O Deva, the flaming ones: With those bring hitherward the Devas.

hymns.title: HYMN XV. Rtu.
hymns.text:
p: O Indra with Rtu.

p: Maruts, with Rtu; sanctify the rite, for ye give precious gifts.

p: Accept  'our offering; with Rtu, for thou art he who giveth wealth.

p: Bring the Devas, Agni, in the three appointed places set them down: Surround them, and with Rtu.

p: Rtus, undissolved, O Indra, is thy friendship's bond.

p: Mitra, Varuna, ye whose ways are firm—a Power that none deceives—, with Rtu ye have reached the rite.

p: The Soma-pressers, fain for wealth, praise the Wealth-giver in the rite, in offerings praise the Deva.

p: May the Wealth-giver grant to us riches that shall be far renowned. These things we gain, among the Devas.

p: He with the Rtu fain would drink, Wealth-giver, from the Nestar's bowl. Haste, give your offering, and depart.

p: Wealth-giver, honour thee with the Rtus, be A Giver bountiful to us.

p: Drink, O Asvins bright with flames, whose acts are pure, who with Rtus accept  'the offering.

p: With Rtu, kind Giver,  'guidest offering: Worship the Devas for the pious man.

hymns.title: HYMN XVI. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: LET thy Bay Steeds bring thee, the Strong, hither to drink the Soma draught— Those, indra, who are bright as suns.

p: Here are the grains bedewed with oil: hither let the Bay Coursers bring Indra upon his easiest car.

p: Indra at early morn we call, indra in course of offering, indra to drink the Soma juice.

p: Come hither, with thy long-maned Steeds, O Indra, to he draught we pour. We call thee when the juice is shed.

p: Come thou to this our song of praise, to the libation poured for thee Drink of it like a stag athirst.

p: Here are the drops of Soma juice expressed on sacred grass: thereof Drink, indra, to increase thy might.

p: Welcome to thee be this our hymn, reaching thy heart, most excellent: Then drink the Soma juice expressed.

p: To every draught of pressed-out juice Indra comes to drink the Soma for delight.

p: Fulfil, O Satakratu, all our wish with horses and with kine: With holy thoughts we sing thy praise.

hymns.title: HYMN XVII. Indra-Varuna
hymns.text:
p: I CRAVE help from the Imperial Lords, from Indra-Varuna. May they Both favour one of us like me.

p: Guardians of men, ye ever come with ready assist at the call Of every singer such as I.

p: Sate you, according to your wish, O Indra-Varuna, with wealth: Fain would we have you nearest us.

p: May we be sharers of the powers, sharers of the benevolence. Of you who give strength bounteously.

p: Indra and Varuna, among givers of thousands, meet for praise, Are Powers who merit highest laud.

p: Through their protection. May we gain great store of wealth, and heap it up enough and still to spare, be ours.

p: O Indra-Varuna, on you for wealth in many a form I call. Still keep ye us victorious.

p: O Indra-Varuna, through our songs that seek to win you to ourselves, Give us at once your sheltering help.

p: O Indra-Varuna, to yo. May fair praise which I offer come, Joint eulogy which ye dignify.

hymns.title: HYMN XVIII. Narasamsa.
hymns.text:
p: O BRAHMAṆASPATI, make him who presses Soma glorious. Even Kaksivan Ausija

p: The rich, the healer of disease, who giveth wealth, increaseth store, the prompt.

p: Let not the foeman's curse, let not a mortal's onslaught fall on us Preserve us, Narasamsa.

p: Ne’er is the mortal hero harmed whom Indra, Narasamsa, and Soma graciously inspire.

p: Do O Narasamsa, and Indra, Soma, Daksina, preserve that mortal from distress.

p: To the Assembly's wondrous Lord, to Indra's lovely Friend who gives Wisdom, have I drawn near in meditation.

p: He without whom no offering, e’en of the wise man, prospers; he stirs up the series of thoughts.

p: He makes the oblation prosper, he promotes the course of offering, our offering goes to the Devas..

p: I have seen Narasamsa, him most resolute, most widely famed, as ’twere the Household Monk of heaven.

hymns.title: HYMN XIX. Agni, Maruts.
hymns.text:
p: To this fair offerings thou art invoked: O Agni, with the Maruts come.

p: No mortal man, no Deva.exceeds thy mental power, O Mighty one: O Agni, with the Maruts come:

p: All Devas devoid of guile, who know the mighty region of mid-air: O Agni, with those Maruts come.

p: The terrible, who sing their song, not to be overcome by might: O Agni, with those Maruts come.

p: Brilliant, and awful in their form, mighty, conquerers of their . O Agni, with those Maruts come.

p: Who sit as Deities in heaven, above the sky-vault's luminous sphere: O Agni, with those Maruts come.

p: Who scatter clouds about the sky, away over the billowy sea: O Agni, with those Maruts come.

p: Who with their bright beams spread them forth over the ocean in their might O Agni, with those Maruts come.

p: For thee, to be thine early draught, O Agni, with the Maruts come.

hymns.title: HYMN XX. Rbhus.
hymns.text:
p: FOR the Celestial Race this song of praise which gives wealth lavishly Was made by singers with their lips.

p: They who for Indra, with their mind, formed horses harnessed by a word, attained by works of offering.

p: They for the two Nasatyas wrought a light car moving every way: They formed a nectar-yielding cow.

p: The Rbhus with effectual prayers, honest, with constant labour, made Their Sire and Mother young again.

p: Together came your gladdening drops with Indra by the Maruts girt, with the Adityas, with the Kings.

p: The ceremonial ladle, wrought newly by the Deva.Tvastar's hand— Four ladles have ye made thereof.

p: Vouchsafe us wealth, to him who pours thrice seven libations, yea, to each Give wealth, pleased with our eulogies.

p: As hosts they held, by pious acts they won themselves, a share in offerings with Devas.

hymns.title: HYMN XXI. Indra and Agni.
hymns.text:
p: INDRA and Agni I invoke fain are we for their song of praise: Chief Soma-drinkers are they both.

p: Praise ye, O men, and glorify Indra and Agni in the holy rites: Sing praise to them in sacred songs.

p: Indra and Agni we invite.

p: Strong Devas, we bid them come to this libation that stands ready here: Indra and Agni, come to us.

p: Indra and Agni, mighty Lords of our assembly, childless be the devouring ones..

p: Watch ye, through this your truthfulness, there in the place of spacious view Indra and Agni, send us bliss.

hymns.title: HYMN XXII. Asvins and Others
hymns.text:
p: WAKEN the Asvin Pair who yoke their car at early morn. May they Approach to drink this Soma juice.

p: We call the Asvins Twain, the Devas borne in a noble car, the best of charioteers, who reach the heavens.

p: Dropping with honey is your whip, Asvins, and full of pleasantness Sprinkle therewith  'the offering.

p: As ye go thither in your car, not far, O Asvins, is the home Of him who offers.

p: For my protection I invoke the golden-handed Savitar. He knoweth, as a Deva, the place.

p: That h. May send us assist, praise the Waters’ Offspring Savitar: Fain are we for his holy ways.

p: We call on him, distributer of wondrous bounty and of wealth, On Savitar who looks on men.

p: Come hither friends, and seat yourselves Savitar, to be praised by us, giving good gifts is beautiful.

p: O Agni, hither bring to us the willing Spouses of the Devas,and Tvastar, H.

p: Most youthful Agni, hither bring their Spouses for aid.

p: Spouses of Heroes, Devas, with whole wing. May they come to us With great protection and with aid.

p: Indrani, Varunani, and Agnayi hither I invite, for weal, to drink the Soma juice.

p: May Heaven and Earth, the Mighty Pair, bedew for us  'our offering, and feed us full with nourishments.

p: Their water rich with fatness, there in the Gandharva's steadfast place, the singers taste through sacred songs.

p: Thornless be thou, O Earth, spread wide before us for a dwelling-place: Vouchsafe us shelter broad and sure.

p: The Devas be gracious unto us even from the place whence Visnu strode Through the seven regions of the earth!

p: Through all this world strode Visnu; thrice his foot he planted, and the  gathered in his footstep's dust.

p: Visnu, the Guardian, he whom none deceiveth, made three steps; thenceforth establishing his high decrees.

p: Look ye on Visnu's works, whereby the Friend of Indra, close-allied, Hath let his holy ways be seen.

p: The princes evermore behold that loftiest place where Visnu islaid as it were an eye in heaven.

p: This, Visnu's station most sublime, the singers, ever vigilant. Lovers of holy song, light up.

hymns.title: HYMN XXIII. Vayu and Others.
hymns.text:
p: STRONG are the Somas; come thou nigh; these offerings have been mixt with milk: Drink, Vayu, the presented draughts.

p: Both Deities who touch the heaven, indra and Vayu we invoke to drink of this our Soma juice.

p: The singers' for their aid, invoke Indra and Vayu, swift as mind, the thousand-eyed, the Lords of thought.

p: Mitra and Varuna, renowned as Devas of consecrated might, We call to drink the Soma juice.

p: Those who by Law uphold the Law, Lords of the shining light of Law, Mitra I call, and Varuna.

p: Let Varuna be our chief defence, let Mitra guard us with all aids Both make us rich exceedingly.

p: Indra, by Maruts girt, we call to drink the Soma juice. May he Sate him in union with his troop.

p: Devas, Marut hosts whom Indra leads, distributers of Pusan's gifts. Hearken ye all unto my cry.

p: With conquering Indra for ally, strike Vrtra down, ye bounteous Devas Let not the wicked master us.

p: We call the Universal Devas, and MarutsH, for passing strong are Prsni's Sons.

p: Fierce comes the Maruts’ thundering voice, like that of conquerors, when ye go Forward to victory, O Men.

p: Born of the laughing lightning. May the Maruts guard us everywhere May they be gracious unto Us.

p: Like some lost animal, drive to us, bright Pusan, him who bears up heaven, Resting on many-coloured grass.

p: Pusan the Bright has found the King, concealed and hidden in a cave, who rests on grass of many hues.

p: An. May he. duly bring to me the six bound closely, through these drops, as one who ploughs with steers brings corn.

p: Along their paths the Mothers go, Sisters of priestly ministrants, Mingling their sweetness with the milk.

p: May Waters gathered near the Sun, and those wherewith the Sun is joined. Speed forth this offering of ours.

p: I call the Waters, Devas, wherein our cattle quench their thirst; Oblations to the Streams be given.

p: Amrit is in the Waters. In the Waters there is healing balm be swift, ye Devas, to give them praise.

p: Within the Waters—Soma thus hath told me—dwell all balms that heal, and Agni, he who blesseth all. The Waters hold all medicines.

p: O Waters, teem with medicine to keep my body safe from harm. So that I lon. May see the Sun.

p: Whatever sin is found in me, whatever evil I have wrought. If I have lied or falsely sworn, Waters, remove it far from me.

p: The Waters I this day have sought, and to their moisture have we come: O Agni, rich in milk, come thou, and with thy splendour cover me.

p: Fill me with splendour, Agni, give offspring and length of days. The Devas shall know me even as I am, and Indra with the Rsis, know.

hymns.title: HYMN XXIV. Varuna and Others.
hymns.text:
p: WHO now is he, what Deva among Immortals, of whose auspicious name we may bethink us? Who shall restore us, that . May see my Father and my Mother?

p: Agni the Deva.the first among the Immortals.of his auspicious name let us bethink us. He shall restore us, that . May see my Father and my Mother.

p: To thee, O Savitar, the Lord of precious things, who helpest us continually, for our share we come—

p: Wealth, highly lauded ere reproach hath fallen on it, which is laid, free from all hatred, in thy hands

p: Through thy protection. May we come to even the height of affluence.

p: Ne’er have those birds that fly through air attained to thy high dominion or thy might or spirit; Nor these the waters that flow on forever, nor hills, abaters of the wind's wild fury.

p: Varuna, King, of hallowed might, sustaineth erect the Tree's stem in the baseless region. Its rays, whose root is high above, stream downward. Dee. May they sink within us, and be hidden.

p: King Varuna hath made a spacious pathway, a pathway for the Sun wherein to travel. Where no way was he made him set his footstep, and warned afar whate’er afflicts the spirit.

p: A hundred balms are thine, O King, a thousand; deep and wide-reaching also be thy favours. Far from us, far away drive thou destruction. Put from us e’en the sin we have committed.

p: Whither by day depart the constellations that shine at night, set high in heaven above us? Varuna's holy laws remain unweakened, and through the night the Moon moves on in splendor

p: I ask this of thee with my meditation adoring; thy worshipper craves this with his oblation. Varuna, stay thou here and be not angry; steal not our life from us, O thou Wide-Ruler.

p: Nightly and daily this one thing they tell me, this too the thought of mine own heart repeateth. May he the Sovran Varuna release us.

p: Bound to three pillars the Aditya made his supplication. Hi. May the Sovran Varuna deliver, wise, ne’er deceived, loosen the bonds that bind him.

p: With bending down, oblations, O Varuna, we deprecate thine anger: Wise Asura, thou King of wide dominion, loosen the bonds of sins by us committed.

p: Loosen the bonds, O Varuna, that hold me, loosen the bonds above, between, and under. So in thy holy la. May we made sinless belong to Aditi, O thou Aditya.

hymns.title: HYMN XXV. Varuna.
hymns.text:
p: WHATEVER law of thine, O Deva, O Varuna, as we are men, Day after day we violate.

p: give us not as a prey to death, to be conquered by thee in wrath, to thy fierce anger when displeased.

p: To gain thy mercy, Varuna, with hymns we bind thy heart, as binds The charioteer his tethered horse.

p: They flee from me dispirited, bent only on obtaining wealth, as to their nests the birds of air.

p: When shall we bring, to be appeased, the Hero, Lord of warrior mighthim, the far-seeing Varuna?

p: This, this with joy they both accept in common: never do they fail The ever-faithful worshipper.

p: He knows the path of birds that fly through heaven, and, Sovran of the sea. He knows the ships that are thereon.

p: True to his holy law, he knows the twelve moons with their progeny: He knows the moon of later birth.

p: He knows the pathway of the wind, the spreading, high, and mighty wind: He knows the Devas who dwell above.

p: Varuna, true to holy law, sits down among his people; he, most wise, sits there to govern all.

p: From thence perceiving he beholds all wondrous things, both what hath been, and what will be done.

p: May that very wise, make fair paths for us all our days: May he prolong our lives for us.

p: Varuna, wearing golden mail, hath clad him in a shining robe. His spies are seated found about.

p: The Deva whom enemies threaten not, nor those who tyrannize o’er men, Nor those whose minds are bent on wrong.

p: He who gives glory to mankind, not glory that is incomplete, to our own bodies giving it.

p: Yearning for the wide-seeing One, my thoughts move onward unto him, as kine unto their pastures move.

p: Once more together let us speak, because my meath is brought: priest-like Thou eatest what is dear to thee.

p: Now s w I him whom al. May see, I s w his car above the earth: He hath accepted these my songs.

p: Varuna, hear this call of mine: be gracious unto us this day Longing for help I cried to thee.

p: Thou, O wise Deva, art Lord of all, thou art the King of earth and heaven Hear, as thou goest on thy way.

p: Release us from the upper bond, untie the bond between, and loose the bonds below, that . May live.

hymns.title: HYMN XXVI. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: O WORTHY of oblation, Lord of prospering powers, assume thy robes, and offer this  'our offering.

p: Sit ever to be chosen, as our Monk, most youthful, through our hymns, O Agni, through our heavenly word.

p: For here a Father for his son, Kinsman for kinsman worshippeth, and Friend, choice-worthy, for his friend.

p: Here let the foe-destroyers sit, Varuna, Mitra, Aryamanlike men, upon our sacred grass.

p: O ancient Herald, be thou glad in this our rite and fellowship: Hearken thou well to these our songs.

p: Whate’er in this perpetual course we offering to Deva.and Deva, that gift is offered up in thee

p: May he be our dear household Lord, Monk, pleasant and, choice-worth. May we, with bright fires, be dear to him.

p: The Devas, adored with brilliant fires. have granted precious wealth to us So, with bright fires, we pray to thee.

p: And, O Immortal One, s. May the eulogies of mortal men Belong to us and thee alike.

p: With all thy fires, O Agni, find pleasure in this  'our offering, and this our speech, O Son of Strength.

hymns.title: HYMN XXVII. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: WITH worship will I glorify thee, Agni, like a long-tailed steed, Imperial Lord of sacred rites.

p: May the far-striding Son of Strength, bringer of great felicity, who pours his gifts like rain, be ours.

p: Lord of all life, from near; from far, do thou, O Agni evermore protect us from the sinful man.

p: O Agni, graciously announce this our oblation to the Devas, and this our newest song of praise.

p: Give us a share of strength most high, a share of strength that is below, a share of strength that is between.

p: Thou dealest gifts, resplendent One; nigh, as with waves of Sindhu, thou Swift streamest to the worshipper.

p: That man is lord of endless strength whom thou protectest in the fight, Agni, or urgest to the fray.

p: Him, whosoever h. May be, no ma. May vanquish, mighty One: Nay, very glorious power is his.

p: May he who dwells with all mankind bear us with war-steeds through the fight, and with the singers win the spoil.

p: Help, thou who knowest lauds, this work, this eulogy to Rudra, him Adorable in every house.

p: May this our Deva, great, limitless, smoke-bannered excellently bright, Urge us to strength and holy thought.

p: Like some rich Lord of me. May he, Agni the banner of the Devas, Refulgent, hear us through our lauds.

p: Glory to Devas, the mighty and the lesser glory to Devas the younger and the elder! Let us, if we have power, pay the Deva.worship: no better offering than this, ye Devas, acknowledge.

hymns.title: HYMN XXVIII. Indra, Varuna, and Mitra.
hymns.text:
p: THERE where the broad-based stone raised on high to press the juices out, O Indra, drink with eager thirst the droppings which the mortar sheds.

p: Where, like broad hips, to hold the juice the platters of the press are laid, O Indra, drink with eager thirst the droppings which the mortar sheds.

p: There where the woman marks and leans the pestle's constant rise and fall, O Indra, drink with eager thirst the droppings which the mortar sheds.

p: Where, as with reins to guide a horse, they bind the churning-staff with cords, O Indra, drink with eager thirst the droppings which the mortar sheds.

p: If of a truth in every house, O Mortar thou art set for work. Here give thou forth thy clearest sound, loud as the drum of conquerors.

p: O Sovran of the Forest, as the wind blows soft in front of thee, Mortar, for Indra press thou forth the Soma juice that h. May drink.

p: Best strength-givers, ye stretch wide jaws, O Sacrificial Implementslike two bay horses champing herbs.

p: Ye Sovrans of the Forest, both swift, with swift pressers press to-day Sweet Soma juice for Indra's drink.

p: Take up in beakers what remains: the Soma on the filter pour, and on the ox-hide set the dregs.

hymns.title: HYMN XXIX. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: O Soma-Drinker, ever true, utterly hopeless though we be, Do thou, O Indra, give us hope of beauteous horses and of kine, in thousands, O most wealthy One.

p: O Lord of Strength, whose jaws are strong, great deeds are thine, the powerful. Do thou, O Indra, give us hope of beauteous horses and of kine, in thousands, O most wealthy One.

p: Lull thou asleep, to wake no more, the pair who on each other look Do thou, O Indra, give us hope of beauteous horses and of kine, in thousands, O most wealthy One.

p: Hero, let hostile spirits sleep, and every gentler genius wake.
p:Do thou, O Indra, give us hope of beauteous horses and of kine, in thousands, O most wealthy One.

p: Conquer this ass,O Indra, who in tones discordant brays to thee: Do thou, O Indra, give us hope of beauteous horses and of kine, in thousands, O most wealthy One.

p: Far distant on the forest fall the tempest in a circling course! Do thou, O Indra, give us hope of beauteous horses and of kine, in thousands, O most wealthy One.

p: Destroy him who in secret injures us: Do thou, O Indra, give us hope of beauteous horses and of kine In thousands, O most wealthy One.

hymns.title: HYMN XXX. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: WEseeking strength fill full your Indra like a well, most liberal, Lord of Hundred Powers,

p: Who lets a hundred of the pure, a thousand of the milk-blent draughts Flow, even as down a depth, to him;

p: When for the strong, the rapturous joy he in this manner hath made room within his belly, like the sea.

p: This is thine own. Thou drawest near, as turns a pigeon to his mate: Thou carest too for this our meditation.

p: O Hero, Lord of Bounties, praised in hymns. May power and joyfulness Be his who sings the laud to thee.

p: Lord of a Hundred Powers, stand up to lend us assist in this fight In others too let us agree.

p: In every need, in every fray we call as friends to assist us Indra the mightiest of all.

p: If he will hear us let him come with assist of a thousand kinds, and all that strengthens, to our call.

p: I call him mighty to resist, the Hero of our ancient home, thee whom my sire invoked of old.

p: We meditate to thee, O much-invoked, rich in all precious gifts, O Friend, Kind Deva.to those who sing thy praise.

p: O Soma-drinker, Thunder-armed, Friend of our lovely-featured dames And of our Soma-drinking friends.

p: Thus, Soma-drinker. May it be; thus, Friend, who wieldest thunder, act To aid each wish as we desire.

p: With Indra splendid feasts be ours, rich in all strengthening things wherewith, Wealthy in food, we may rejoice.

p: Like thee, thyself, the singers' Friend, thou movest, as it were, besought, Bold One, the axle of the car.

p: That, Satakratu, thou to grace and please thy praisers, as it were, Stirrest the axle with thy strength.

p: With champing, neighing loudly-snorting horses Indra hath ever won himself great treasure.s. A car of gold hath he whose deeds are wondrous received from us, and let us too receive it.

p: Come, Asvins, with enduring strength wealthy in horses and in kine, and gold, O ye of wondrous deeds.

p: Your chariot yoked for both alike, immortal, ye of mighty acts, travels, O Asvins, in the sea.

p: High on the forehead of the Bull one chariot wheel ye ever keep, the other round the sky revolves.

p: What mortalO Immortal Deva, enjoyeth thee? Where lovest thou? To whom, O radiant, dost thou go?

p: For we have had thee in our thoughts whether anear or far away.

p: Hither, O Deva of the sky, come thou with these thy strengthenings, and send thou riches down to us.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXI. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: Thou, Agni, wast the earliest Angiras, a Seer; thou wast, a Deva.thyself, the Devas’ auspicious Friend. After thy holy ordinance the Maruts, sage, active through wisdom, with their glittering spears, were born.

p: O Agni the best and earliest Angiras, fulfillest as a Sage the holy law of Devas. Sprung from two mothers, wise, through all existence spread, resting in many a place for sake of living man.

p: To Matarisvan first thou, Agni, wast disclosed, and to Vivasvan through thy noble inward power. Heaven and Earth, Vasu! shook at the choosing of the Monk: the burthen thou didst bear, didst worship mighty Devas.

p: Agni thou madest heaven to thunder for mankind; thou, yet more pious, for pious Pururavas. When thou art rapidly freed from thy parents, first eas ward they bear thee round, and, after, to the west.

p: Thou, Agni, art a Bull who makes our store increase, to be invoked by him who lifts the ladle up. Well knowing the oblation with the hallowing word, uniting all who live, thou lightenest first our folk

p: Agni, thou savest in the synod when pursued e’en him, farseeing One! who walks in evil ways. Thou, when the heroes fight for spoil which men rush, round, slayest in war the many by the hands of few.

p: For glory, Agni, day by day, thou liftest up the mortal man to highest immortality, Even thou who yearning for both races givest them great bliss, and to the prince grantest abundant food.

p: O Agni, highly lauded, make our singer famous that h. May win us store of riches: May we improve the rite with new performance. O Earth and Heaven, with all the Devas, protect us.

p: O blameless Agni lying in thy Parents' lap, a Deva among the Devas, be watchful for our good. Former of bodies, be the singer's Providence: all good things hast thou s wn for him, auspicious One!

p: Agni, thou art our Providence, our Father thou: we are thy brethren and thou art our spring of life. In thee, rich in good heroes, guard of high decrees, meet hundred, thousand treasure.s, O infallible!

p: Thee, Agni, have the Devas made the first living One for living man, Lord of the house of Nahusa. Ila they made the teacher of the sons of men, what time a Son was born to the father of my race.

p: Worthy to be revered, O Agni, Deva, preserve our wealthy patrons with thy assists, and ourselves. Guard of our seed art thou, aiding our cows to bear, incessantly protecting in thy holy way.

p: Agni, thou art a guard close to the pious man; kindled art thou, four-eyed! for him who is unarmed. With fond heart thou acceptest e’en the poor man's prayer, when he hath brought his gift to gain security.

p: Thou, Agni gainest for the loudly-praising priest the highest wealth, the object of a man's desire. Thou art called Father, caring even for the weak, and wisest, to the simple one thou teachest lore.

p: Agni, the man who giveth guerdon to the monks, like well-s wn armour thou guardest on every side. He who with grateful food shows kindness in his house, an offerer to the living, is the type of heaven.

p: Pardon, we meditate, this sin of ours, O Agni.the path which we have trodden, widely straying, Dear Friend and Father, caring for the pious, who speedest nigh and who inspirest mortals.

p: As erst to Manus, to Yayati, Angiras, so Angiras! pure Agni! come thou to our hall. Bring hither the celestial host and seat them here upon the sacred grass, and offer what they love.

p: By this our meditation be thou, O Agni, strengthened, prayer made by us after our power and knowledge. Lead thou us, therefore, to increasing riches; endow us with thy strength-bestowing favour.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: I WILL declare the manly deeds of Indra, the first that he achieved, the Thunder-wielder. He conquered the Dragon disclosed the waters, and cleft the channels of the mountain torrents.

p: He slew the Dragon lying on the mountain: his heavenly bolt of thunder Tvastar fashioned. Like lowing kine in rapid flow descending the waters glided downward to the ocean.

p: Impetuous as a bull, he chose the Soma and in three sacred beakers drank the juices. Maghavan grasped the thunder for his weapon, and smote to death this firstborn of the dragons.

p: When, indra, thou hadst slain the dragon's firstborn, and overcome the charms of the enchanters, then, giving life to Sun and Dawn and Heaven, thou foundest not one foe to stand against thee.

p: Indra with his own great and deadly thunder smote into pieces Vrtra, worst of Vrtras. As trunks of trees, what time the axe hath felled them, low on the earth so lies the prostrate Dragon.

p: He, like a mad weak warrior, challenged Indra, the great impetuous many-subduing Hero. He, brooking not the clashing of the weapons, crushed—Indra's foe—the shattered forts in falling.

p: Footless and handless still he challenged Indra, who smote him with his bolt between the shoulders. Emasculate yet claiming manly vigour, thus Vrtra lay with scattered limbs dissevered.

p: There as he lies like a bank-bursting river, the waters taking courage flow above him. The Dragon lies beneath the feet of torrents which Vrtra with his greatness had encompassed.

p: Then humbled was the strength of Vrtra's mother. Indra hath cast bolt against her. The mother was above, the son was under and like a cow beside her calf lay Danu.

p: Rolled in the midst of never-ceasing currents flowing without a rest forever onward. The waters bear off Vrtra's nameless body: the foe of Indra sank to during darkness.

p: Guarded by Ahi stood the thralls of Dasas, the waters stayed like kine held by the robber. But he, when he had smitten Vrtra, opened the cave wherein the floods had been imprisoned.

p: A horse's tail wast thou when he, O Indra, smote on thy bolt; thou, Deva without a second, Thou hast won back the kine, has won the Heavens. thou hast let loose to flow the Seven Rivers.

p: Nothing availed him lightning, nothing thunder, hailstorm or mist which had spread around him: When Indra and the Dragon strove in battle, Maghavan gained the victory forever.

p: Whom s west thou to avenge the Dragon, indra, that fear possessed thy heart when thou hadst slain him; That, like a hawk affrighted through the regions, thou crossedst nine-and-ninety flowing rivers?

p: Indra is King of all that moves and moves not, of creatures tame and horned, the Thunder-wielder. Over all living men he rules as Sovran, containing all as spokes within the felly.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXIII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: Come, fain for booty let us seek to Indra: yet more shall he increase his care that guides us. Will not the Indestructible endow us with perfect knowledge of this wealth, of cattle?

p: I fly to him invisible Wealth-giver as flies the falcon to his cherished eyrie, with fairest hymns of praise adoring Indra, whom those who laud him must invoke in battle.

p: Mid all his host, he bindeth on the quiver: he driveth cattle from what foe he pleaseth: Gathering up great store of riches, indra. be thou no trafficker with us, most mighty.

p: Thou slewest with thy bolt the wealthy Dasyu, alone, yet going with thy helpers, indra! Far from the floor of heaven in all directions, the ancient riteless ones fled to destruction.

p: Fighting with pious worshippers, the riteless turned and fled, indra! with averted faces. When thou, fierce Lord of the Bay Steeds, the Stayer, blewest from earth and heaven and sky the godless.

p: They met in fight the army of the blameless: then the Navagvas put forth all their power. They, like emasculates with men contending, fled, conscious, by steep paths from Indra, scattered.

p: Whether they weep or laugh, thou hast o’erthrown them, O Indra, on the sky's extremest limit. The Dasyu thou hast burned from heaven, and welcomed the prayer of him who pours the juice and lauds thee.

p: Adorned with their array of gold and jewels, they o’er the earth a covering veil extended. Although they hastened, they o’ercame not Indra: their spies he compassed with the Sun of morning.

p: As thou enjoyest heaven and earth, O Indra, on every side surrounded with thy greatness, So thou with monks hast blown away the Dasyu, and those who worship not with those who worship.

p: They who pervaded earth's extremest limit subdued not with their charms the Wealth-bestower: Indra, the Bull, made his ally the thunder, and with its light milked cows from out the darkness.

p: The waters flowed according to their nature; he raid the navigable streams waxed mighty. Then Indra, with his spirit concentrated, smote him forever with his strongest weapon.

p: Indra broke through Ilibisa's strong castles, and Susna with his horn he cut to pieces: Thou, Maghavan, for all his might and swiftness, slewest thy fighting foeman with thy thunder

p: Fierce on his enemies fell Indra's weapon: with. his sharp bull he rent their forts in pieces. He with his thunderbolt dealt blows on Vrtra; and conquered, executing all his purpose.

p: Indra, thou helpest Kutsa whom thou lovedst, and guardedst brave Dasadyu when he battled, the dust of trampling horses rose to heaven, and Svitra's son stood up again for conquest.

p: Svitra's mild steer, O Maghavan thou helpest in combat for the land, mid Tugra's houses. Long stood they there before the task was ended: thou wast the master of the foemen's treasure..

hymns.title: HYMN XXXIV. Asvins.
hymns.text:
p: Ye who observe this day be with us even thrice: far-stretching is you bounty, Asvins and your course. To you, as to a cloak in winter, we cleave close: you are to be drawn nigh unto us by the wise.

p: Three are the fellies in your honey-bearing car, that travels after Soma's loved one, as all know. Three are the pillars set upon it for support: thrice journey ye by night, O Asvins, thrice by day.

p: Thrice in the self-same day, ye Devas who banish want, sprinkle ye thrice to-day  'our offering with meath; And thrice vouchsafe us store of food with plenteous strength, at evening, O ye Asvins, and at break of day.

p: Thrice come ye to our home, thrice to the righteous folk, thrice triply aid the man who well deserves your help. Thrice, O ye Asvins, bring us what shall make us glad; thrice send us store of food as nevermore to fail.

p: Thrice, O ye Asvins, bring to us abundant wealth: thrice in the Devas’ assembly, thrice assist our thoughts. Thrice, grant ye us prosperity, thrice grant us fame; for the Sun's daughter hath mounted your three-wheeled car.

p: Thrice, Asvins, grant to us the heavenly medicines, thrice those of earth and thrice those that the waters hold, Favour and health and strength bestow upon my son; triple protection, Lords of Splendour, grant to him.

p: Thrice are ye to be worshipped day by day by us: thrice, O ye Asvins, ye travel around the earth. Car-borne from far away, O ye Nasatyas, come, like vital air to bodies, come ye to the three.

p: Thrice, O ye Asvins, with the Seven Mother Streams; three are the jars, the triple offering is prepared. Three are the worlds, and moving on above the sky ye guard the firm-set vault of heaven through days and nights.

p: Where are the three wheels of your triple chariot, where are the three seats thereto firmly fastened? When will ye yoke the mighty ass that draws it, to bring you to  'our offering. Nasatyas?

p: Nasatyas, come: the sacred gift is offered up; drink the sweet juice with lips that know the sweetness well. Savitar sends, before the dawn of day, your car, fraught with oil, various-coloured, to  'our offering.

p: Come, O Nasatyas, with the thrice-eleven Devas; come, O ye Asvins, to the drinking of the meath. Make long our days of life, and wipe out all our sins: ward off our enemies; be with us evermore.

p: Borne in your triple car, O Asvins, bring us present prosperity with noble offspring. I cry to you who hear me for protection be ye our helpers where men win the booty.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXV. Savitar.
hymns.text:
p: AGNI I first invoke for our prosperity; I call on Mitra, Varuna, to aid us here. I call on Night who gives rest to all moving life; I call on Savitar the Deva.to lend us help.

p: Throughout the dusky firmament advancing, laying to rest the immortal and the mortal, Borne in his golden chariot he cometh, Savitar, Deva who looks on every creature..

p: The Deva.moves by the upward path, the downward; with two bright Bays, adorable, he journeys. Savitar comes, the Deva.from the far distance, and chases from us all distress and sorrow.

p: His chariot decked with pearl, of various colours, lofty, with golden pole, the Deva.hath mounted, the many-rayed One, Savitar the holy, bound, bearing power and might, for darksome regions.

p: Drawing the gold-yoked car his Bays, white-footed, have manifested light to all the peoples. Held in the lap of Savitar, divine One, all men, all beings have their place forever.

p: Three heavens there are; two Savitar's, adjacent: in Yama's world is one, the home of heroes, as on a linch-pin, firm, rest things immortal: he who hath known it let him here declare it.

p: He, strong of wing, hath lightened up the regions, deep-quivering Asura, the gentle Leader. Where now is Surya, where is one to tell us to what celestial sphere his ray hath wandered?

p: The earth's eight points his brightness hath illumined, three desert regions and the Seven Rivers. Deva.Savitar the gold-eyed hath come hither, giving choice treasure.s unto him who worships.

p: The golden-handed Savitar, far-seeing, goes on his way between the earth and heaven, Drives away sickness, bids the Sun approach us, and spreads the bright sky through the darksome region.

p: May he, gold-handed Asura, kind Leader, come hither to us with his help and favour. Driving off Raksasas and Yatudhanas, the Indu is present, praised in hymns at evening.

p: O Savitar, thine ancient dustless pathways are well established in the air's mid-region: O Deva, come by those paths so fair to travel, preserve thou us from harm this day, and bless us.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXVI. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: WITH words sent forth in holy hymns, Agni we supplicate, the Lord Of many families who duly serve the Devas, yea, him whom others also praise.

p: Men have won Agni, him who makes their strength abound: we, with oblations, worship thee. Our gracious-minded Helper in our deeds of might, be thou, O Excellent, this day.

p: Thee for our messenger we choose, thee, the Omniscient, for our Monk. The flames of thee the mighty are spread wide around: thy splendour reaches to the sky.

p: The Devas enkindle thee their ancient messenger.Varuna, Mitra, Aryaman. That mortal man, O Agni, gains through thee all wealth, who hath poured offerings unto thee.

p: Thou, Agni, art a cheering Monk, Lord of the House, men's messenger: All constant high decrees established by the Devas, gathered together, meet in thee.

p: In thee, the auspicious One, O Agni, youthfullest, each sacred gift is offered up: This day, and after, gracious, worship thou our Devas, that we may have heroic sons.

p: To him in his own splendour bright draw near in worship the devout. Men kindle Agni with their offerings gifts, victorious o’er the enemies.

p: Vrtra they smote and slew, and made the earth and heaven and firmament a wide abode. The glorious Bull, invoked, hath stood at Kanva's side: loud neighed the Steed in frays for kine.

p: Seat thee, for thou art mighty; shine, best entertainer of the Devas. Worthy of sacred food, praised Agni! loose the smoke, ruddy and beautiful to see.

p: Bearer of offerings, whom, best sacrificing Monk, the Devas for Manu's sake ordained. Whom Kanva, whom Medhyatithi made the source of wealth, and Vrsan and Upastuta.

p: Him, Agni, whom Medhyatithi, whom Kanva kindled for his ritehim these our songs of praise, him, Agni, we extol: his powers shine out preeminent.

p: Make our wealth perfect thou, O Agni, Lord divine: for thou hast kinship with the Devas. Thou rulest as a King o’er widely-famous strength: be good to us, for thou art great.

p: Stand up erect to lend us aid, stand up like Savitar the Deva. Erect as strength-bestower we call aloud, with unguents and with monks, on thee.

p: Erect, preserve us from sore trouble; with thy flame burn thou each ravening demon dead. Raise thou us up that we may walk and live: so thou shalt find our worship mid the Devas.

p: Preserve us, Agni, from the fiend, preserve us from malicious wrong. Save us from him who fain would injure us or subdue, most Youthful, thou with lofty light.

p: Smite down as with a club, thou who hast fire for teeth, smite thou the wicked, right and left. Let not the man who plots against us in the night, nor any foe prevail o’er us.

p: Agni hath given heroic might to Kanva, and felicity: Agni hath helped our friends, hath helped Medhyatithi, hath helped Upastuta to win.

p: We call on Ugradeva, Yadu, Turvasa, by means of Agni, from afar; Agni, bring Navavastva and Brhadratha, Turviti, to subdue the foe.

p: Manu hath stablished thee a light, Agni, for all the race of men: Sprung from the Law, oil-fed, for Kanva hast thou blazed, thou whom the people reverence.

p: The flames of Agni full of splendour and of might are fearful, not to be approached. Consume forever all demons and sorcerers, consume thou each devouring fiend.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXVII. Maruts.
hymns.text:
p: SING forth, O Kanvas, to your band of Maruts unassailable, Sporting, resplendent on their car

p: They who, self-luminous, were born together, with the spotted deer, Spears, swords, and glittering ornaments.

p: One hears, as though ’twere close at hand, the cracking of the whips they hold They gather glory on their way.

p: Now sing ye forth the Deva.given hymn to your exultant Marut host, the fiercely-vigorous, the strong.

p: Praise ye the Bull among the cows; for ’tis the Maruts’ sportive band: It strengthened as it drank the rain.

p: Who is your mightiest. Heroes, when, O shakers of the earth and heaven, Ye shake them like a garment's hem?

p: At your approach man holds him down before the fury of your wrath: The rugged-jointed mountain yields.

p: They at whose racings forth the earth, like an age-weakened lord of men, Trembles in terror on their ways.

p: Strong is their birth: vigour have they to issue from their Mother; strength, Yea, even twice enough, is theirs.

p: And these, the Sons, the Singers, in their racings have enlarged the bounds, So that the kine must walk knee-deep.

p: Before them, on the ways they go, they drop this offspring of the cloud, Long, broad, and inexhaustible.

p: O Maruts, as your strength is great, so have ye cast men down on earth, So have ye made the mountains fall.

p: The while the Maruts pass along, they talk together on the way: Doth any hear them as they speak?

p: Come quick with swift steeds, for ye have worshippers among Kanva's sons May you rejoice among them well.

p: All is prepared for your delight. We are their servants evermore, to live as long as lif. May last.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXVIII. Maruts.
hymns.text:
p: WHAT now? When will ye take us by both hands, as a dear sire his son, Devas, for whom sacred grass is clipped?

p: Now whither? To what goal of yours go ye in heaven, and not on earth? Where do your cows disport themselves?

p: Where are your newest favours shown? Where, Maruts, your prosperity? Where all your high felicities?

p: If, O ye Maruts, ye the Sons whom Prsni bore, were mortal, and Immortal he who sings your praise.

p: Then never were your praiser loathed like a wild beast in pasture-land, Nor should he go on Yama's path.

p: Let not destructive plague on plague hard to be conquered, strike its down: Let each, with drought, depart from us.

p: Truly, they the fierce and mighty Sons of Rudra send their windless Rain e’en on the desert places.

p: Like a cow the lightning lows and follows, motherlike, her youngling, when their rain-flood hath been loosened.

p: When they inundate the earth they spread forth darkness e’en in day time, with the water-laden rain-cloud.

p: O Maruts, at your voice's sound this earthly habitation shakes, and each man reels who dwells therein.

p: O Maruts, with your strong-hoofed steeds, unhindered in their courses, haste Along the bright embanked streams.

p: Firm be the fellies of your wheels, steady your horses and your cars, an. May your reins be fashioned well.

p: Invite thou hither with this song, for praise, Agni the Lord of Prayerhim who is fair as Mitra is.

p: Form in thy mouth the hymn of praise expand thee like, a rainy cloud Sing forth the measured eulogy.

p: Sing glory to the Marut host, prais worthy, tuneful, vigorous: Here let the Strong Ones dwell with us.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXIX Maruts.
hymns.text:
p: WHEN thus, like flame, from far away, Maruts, ye cast your measure forth, to whom go Ye, to whom, O shakers of the earth, moved by whose wisdom, whose design?

p: Strong let your weapons be to drive away your foes, firm for resistance let them be. Yea, passing glorious must be your warrior might, not as a guileful mortal's strength.

p: When what is strong ye overthrow, and whirl about each ponderous thing. Heroes, your course is through the forest trees of earth, and through the fissures of the rocks.

p: Consumers of your foes, no enemy of yours is found in heaven or on the earth: Ye Rudras. May the strength, held in this bond, be yours, to bid defiance even now.

p: They make the mountains rock and reel, they rend the forest-kings apart. Onward, ye Maruts, drive, like creatures drunk with wine, ye, Devas with all your company.

p: Ye to your chariot have yoked the spotted deer: a red deer, as a leader, draws. Even the Earth herself listened as ye came near, and men were sorely terrified.

p: O Rudras, quickly we desire your assist for this work of ours. Come to us with your aid as in the days of old, so now for frightened Kanva's sake.

p: Should any monstrous foe, O Maruts, sent by you or sent by mortals threaten us, Tear ye him from us with your power and with your might, and with the assists that are yours.

p: For ye, the worshipful and wise, have guarded Kanva perfectly. O Maruts, come to us with full protecting help, as lightning flashes seek the rain.

p: Whole strength have ye, O Bounteous Ones; perfect, earth-shakers, is your might. Maruts, against the poet's wrathful enemy send ye an enemy like a dart.

hymns.title: HYMN XL. Narasamsa
hymns.text:
p: O BRAHMAṆASPATI, stand up: Deva-serving men we pray to thee. May they who give good gifts, the Maruts, come to us. Indra, most swift, be thou with them.

p: O Son of Strength, each mortal calls to thee for aid when spoil of battle waits for him. O Maruts. May this man who loves you well obtain wealth of good steeds and hero might.

p: May Narasamsa draw nigh. May Sunrta the Deva come, and Devas bring to this rite which gives the five-fold gift the Hero, lover of mankind.

p: He who bestows a noble guerdon on the Sage wins fame that never shall decay. For him we offer sacred hero-giving food, peerless and conquering easily.

p: Now Narasamsa speaks forth aloud the solemn hymn of prais wherein Indra and Varuna, Mitra, Aryaman, the Devas, have made their dwelling place.

p: May we in holy synods, Devas! recite that hymn, peerless, that brings felicity. If you, O Heroes, graciously accept this word. May it obtain all bliss from you.

p: Who shall approach the pious? Who the man whose sacred grass is trimmed? The offerer with his folk advances more and more: he fills his house with precious things.

p: He amplifies his lordly might, with kings he subdues: e’en mid alarms he dwells secure In great or lesser fight none checks him, none subdues.the wielder of the thunderbolt.

hymns.title: HYMN XLI. Varuna, Mitra, Aryaman.
hymns.text:
p: NE’ER is he injured whom the Devas Varuna, Mitra, Aryaman, the excellently wise, protect.

p: He prospers ever, free from scathe, whom they, as with full hands, enrich, whom they preserve from every foe.

p: The Kings drive far away from him his troubles and his enemies, and lead him safely o’er distress.

p: Thornless, Adityas, is the path, easy for him who seeks the Law: With him is naught to anger you.

p: What offering Adityas, ye Heroes guide by the path direct. May that come nigh unto your thought.

p: That mortal, ever unsubdued, gains wealth and every precious thing, and children also of his own.

p: How, my friends, shall we prepare Aryaman's and Mitra's laud, Glorious food of Varuna?

p: I point not out to you a man who strikes the pious, or reviles: Only with hymns I call you nigh.

p: Let him not love to speak ill words: but fear the One who holds all four within his hand, until they fall.

hymns.title: HYMN XLII. Pusan.
hymns.text:
p: SHORTEN our ways, O Pusan, move aside obstruction in the path: Go close before us, cloud-born Deva.

p: Drive, pusan, from our road the wolf, the wicked inauspicious wolf, who lies in wait to injure us.

p: Who lurks about the path we take, the robber with a guileful heart: Far from the road chase him away.

p: Tread with thy foot and trample out the firebrand of the wicked one, the double-tongued, whoe’er he be.

p: Wise Pusan, Wonder-Worker, we claim of thee now the aid where thou furtheredst our sires of old.

p: So, Lord of all prosperity, best wielder of the golden sword, make riches easy to be won.

p: Past all pursuers lead us, make pleasant our path and fair to tread: O Pusan, find thou power for this.

p: Lead us to meadows rich in grass: send on our way no early heat: O Pusan, find thou power for this.

p: Be gracious to us, fill us full, give, feed us, and invigorate: O Pusan, find thou power for this.

p: No blame have we for Pusan; him we magnify with songs of praise: We seek the Mighty One for wealth.

hymns.title: HYMN XLIII. Rudra.
hymns.text:
p: WHAT shall we sing to Rudra, strong, most bounteous, excellently wise, that shall be dearest to his heart?

p: Tha. May grant the grace of Rudra to our folk, our kine, Our cattle and our progeny;

p: That Mitra and that Varuna, that Rudr. May remember us, Yea, all the Devas with one accord.

p: To Rudra Lord of offerings, of hymns and balmy medicines, We meditate for joy and health and strength.

p: He shines in splendour like the Sun, refulgent as bright gold is he, the good, the best among the Devas.

p: May he grant health into our steeds, wellbeing to our rams and ewes, to men, to women, and to kine.

p: O Soma, set thou upon us the glory of a hundred men, the great renown of mighty chiefs.

p: Let not malignities, nor those who trouble Soma, hinder us. Indu, give us a share of strength.

p: Soma! head, central point, love these; Soma! know these as serving thee, Children of thee Immortal, at the highest place of holy law.

hymns.title: HYMN XLIV. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: IMMORTAL Jatavedas, thou many-hued fulgent gift of Dawn, Agni, this day to him who pays oblations bring the Devas who waken with the morn.

p: For thou art offering-bearer and loved messenger, the charioteer of offering: Accordant with the Asvins and with Dawn grant us heroic strength and lofty fame.

p: As messenger we choose to-day Agni the good whom many love, Smoke-bannered spreader of the light, at break of day glory of offerings rites.

p: Him noblest and most youthful, richly worshipped guest, dear to the men who offer giftshim, Agni Jatavedas, I beseech at dawn that h. May bring the Devas to us.

p: Thee, Agni, will I glorify, deathless nourisher of the world, Immortal, offering-bearer, meet for sacred food, preserver, best at offering.

p: Tell good things to thy praiser, O most youthful Deva, as richly worshipped, honey-tongued, and, granting to Praskanva lengthened days of life, show honour to the Heavenly Host.

p: For the men, Agni, kindle thee as all possessor and as Monk; So Agni, much-invoked, bring hither with all speed the Devas, the excellently wise,

p: At dawn of day, at night, Usas and Savitar, the Asvins, Bhaga, Agni's self: Skilled in fair rites, with Soma poured, the Kanvas light thee, the oblation-wafting Deva

p: For, Agni, Lord of offering and messenger of men art thou: Bring thou the Devas who wake at dawn who see the light, this day to drink the Soma juice.

p: Thou shonest forth, O Agni, after former dawns, all visible, O rich in light. Thou art our help in battle-strife, the Friend of man, the great Sage of offeirng.

p: Like Manu, we will stablish thee, Agni, performer of the rite, invoker, ministering Monk, exceeding wise, the swift immortal messenger.

p: When as the Devas’ High Monk, by many loved, thou dost their mission as their nearest Friend, then, like the far-resounding billows of the flood, thy flames, O Agni, roar aloud.

p: Hear, Agni, who hast ears to hear, with all thy train of escort Devas; Let Mitra, Aryaman, seeking betimes our rite, seat them upon the sacred grass.

p: Let those who strengthen Law, who bountifully give, the life-tongued Maruts, hear our praise. May Law-supporting Varuna with the Asvins twain and Usas, drink the Soma juice.

hymns.title: HYMN XLV. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: WORSHIP the Vasus, Agni! here, the Rudras, the Adityas, all Who spring from Manu, those who know fair rites, who pour their blessings down.

p: Agni, the Devas who understand give ear unto the worshipper: Lord of Red Steeds, who lovest song, bring thou those Three-and-Thirty Devas.

p: O Jatavedas, great in act, hearken thou to Praskanva's call, as Priyamedha erst was heard, Atri, Virupa, Angiras.

p: The sons of Priyamedha skilled in lofty praise have called for help On Agni who with fulgent flame is Ruler of all holy rites.

p: Hear thou, invoked with holy oil, bountiful giver of rewards, these eulogies, whereby the sons of Kanva call thee to their aid.

p: O Agni, loved by many, thou of fame most wondrous, in their homes Men call on thee whose hair is flame, to be the bearer of their gifts.

p: Thee, Agni, best to find out wealth, most widely famous, quick to hear, Singers have stablished in their rites Herald and ministering Monk.

p: Singershave made thee, Agni, hasten to the feast, Great light to mortal worshipper, what time they bring the sacred gift.

p: Good, bounteous, Son of Strength, this day seat here on sacred grass the Devas Who come at early morn, the host of heaven, to drink the Soma juice

p: Bring with joint invocations thou, O Agni, the celestial host: Here  bounteous Devas drink this expressed ere yesterday.

hymns.title: HYMN XLVI. Asvins.
hymns.text:
p: Now Morning with her earliest light shines forth, dear Daughter of the Sky: High, Asvins, I extol your praise,

p: Sons of the Sea, mighty to save discoverers of riches, ye Devas with deep thought who find out wealth.

p: Your giant coursers hasten on over the region all in flames,  When your car flies with winged steeds.

p: He, liberal, lover of the flood, Lord of the House, the vigilant, Chiefs! with oblations feeds you full.

p: Ye have regard unto our hymns, Nasatyas, thinking of our words: Drink boldly of the Soma juice.

p: Vouchsafe to us, O Asvin Pair, such strength as, with attendant light, may through the darkness carry us.

p: Come in the ship of these our hymns to bear you to the hither shore O Asvins, harness ye the car.

p: The heaven's wide vessel is your own on the flood's shore your chariot waits Drops, with the hymn, have been prepared.

p: Kanvas, the drops are in the heaven; the wealth is at the waters' place: Where will ye manifest your form?

p: Light came to lighten up the branch, the Sun appeared as it were gold: And with its tongue shone forth the dark.

p: The path of offering was made to travel to the farther goal: The road of heaven was manifest.

p: The singer of their praise awaits whatever grace the Asvins give, who save when Soma gladdens them.

p: Ye dwellers with Vivasvan come, auspicious, as to Manu. come to the offering and our praise.

p: O circumambient Asvins, Dawn follows the brightness of your way: Approve with beams our solemn rites.

p: Drink ye of our libations, grant protection, O ye Asvins Twain, with aids which non. May interrupt.

hymns.title: HYMN XLVII. Asvins.
hymns.text:
p: ASVINS, for you who strengthen Law this sweetest Soma hath been shed. Drink this expressed ere yesterday and give riches to him who offers it.

p: Come, O ye Asvins, mounted on your triple car three-seated, beautiful of form To you at offerings the Kanvas send the prayer: graciously listen to their call.

p: O Asvins, ye who strengthen Law, drink ye this sweetest Soma juice. Borne on your wealth-fraught car come ye this day to him who offers, ye of wondrous deeds.

p: Omniscient Asvins, on the thrice-heaped grass bedew with the sweet juice  'the offering. The sons of Kanva, striving heavenward, call on you with draughts of Soma juice out-poured.

p: O Asvins, with those aids wherewith ye guarded Kanva carefully, Keep us, O Lords of Splendour: drink the Soma juice, ye strengtheners of holy law.

p: O MightyOnes, ye gave Sudas abundant food, brought on your treasure.-laden car; So now vouchsafe to us the wealth which many crave, either from heaven or from the sea.

p: Nasatyas, whether ye be far away or close to Turvasa, Borne on your lightly-rolling chariot come to us, together with the sunbeams come.

p: So let your coursers bring you to our libations here. Bestowing food on him who acts and gives aright, sit, Chiefs, upon the sacred grass.

p: Come, O Nasatyas, on your car decked with a sunbright canopy, Whereon ye ever bring wealth to the worshipper, to drink the Soma's pleasant juice.

p: With lauds and songs of praise we call them down to us, that they, most rich. May assist us; For ye have ever in the Kanvas' well-loved house, O Asvins, drank the Soma.

hymns.title: HYMN XLVIII. Dawn.
hymns.text:
p: DAWN on us with prosperity, O Usas, Daughter of the Sky, Dawn with great glory, Deva, Lady of the Light, dawn thou with riches, Bounteous One.

p: They, bringing steeds and kine, boon-givers of all wealth, have oft sped forth to lighten us. O Usas, waken up for me the sounds of joy: send us the riches of the great.

p: Usas hath dawned, and now shall dawn, the Deva, driver forth of cars Which, as she cometh nigh, have fixed their thought on her, like glory-seekers on the flood.

p: Here Kanva, chief of Kanva's race, sings forth aloud the glories of the heroes’ names. The. princes who, O Usas, as thou comest near, direct their thoughts to liberal gifts.

p: Like a good matron Usas comes carefully tending everything: Rousing all life she stirs all creatures that have feet, and makes the birds of air fly up.

p: She sends the busy forth, each man to his pursuit: delay she knows not as she springs. O rich in opulence, after thy dawning birds that have flown forth no longer rest.

p: This Dawn hath yoked her steeds afar, beyond the rising of the Sun: Borne on a hundred chariots she, auspicious Dawn, advances on her way to Men.

p: To meet her glance all living creatures bend them down: Excellent One, she makes the light. Usas, the Daughter of the Sky, the opulent, shines foes and enmities away.

p: Shine on us with thy radiant light, O Usas, Daughter of the Sky, Bringing to us great store of high felicity, and beaming on our solemn rites.

p: For in thee is each living creature.'s breath and life, when, Excellent! thou dawnest forth. Borne on thy lofty car, O Lady of the Light, hear, thou of wondrous wealth, our call.

p: O Usas, win thyself the strength which among men is wonderful. Bring thou thereby the pious unto holy rites, those who as monks sing praise to thee.

p: Bring from the firmament, O Usas, all the Devas, that the, may drink our Soma juice, and, being what thou art, vouchsafe us kine and steeds, strength meet for praise and hero might.

p: May Usas whose auspicious rays are seen resplendent round about, Grant us great riches, fair in form, of all good things, wealth which light labou. May attain.

p: Mighty One, whom the Rsis of old time invoked for their protection and their help, O Usas, graciously answer our songs of praise with bounty and with brilliant light.

p: Usas, as thou with light to day hast opened the twin doors of heaven, So grant thou us a dwelling wide and free from foes. O Deva, give us food with kine.

p: Bring us to wealth abundant, sent in every shape, to plentiful refreshing food, to all-subduing splendour, Usas, Mighty One, to strength, thou rich in spoil and wealth.

hymns.title: HYMN XLIX. Dawn.
hymns.text:
p: E'EN from above the sky's bright realm come, Usas, by auspicious ways: Let red steeds bear thee to the house of him who pours the offering.

p: The chariot which thou mountest, fair of shape, O Usas light to move. Therewith, O Deva of the sky, aid men of noble fame today.

p: Bright Usas, when thy times return, all quadrupeds and bipeds stir, and round about flock winged birds from all the boundaries of heaven.

p: Thou dawning with thy beams of light illumest all the radiant realm. Thee, as thou art, the Kanvas, fain for wealth, have called with sacred songs.

hymns.title: HYMN L. Surya.
hymns.text:
p: HIS bright rays bear him up aloft, the Deva who knoweth all that lives, Surya, that al. May look on him.

p: The constellations pass away, like thieves, together with their beams, before the all-beholding Sun.

p: His herald rays are seen afar refulgent o’er the world of menlike flames of fire that burn and blaze.

p: Swift and all beautiful art thou, O Surya, maker of the light, Illuming all the radiant realm.

p: Thou goest to the hosts of Devas, thou comest hither to mankind, Hither all light to be beheld.

p: With that same eye of thine wherewith thou lookest brilliant Varuna, Upon the busy race of men,

p: Traversing sky and wide mid-air, thou metest with thy beams our days, Sun, seeing all things that have birth.

p: Seven Bay Steeds harnessed to thy car bear thee, O thou farseeing One, Deva, Surya, with the radiant hair.

p: Surya hath yoked the pure bright Seven, the daughters of the car; with these, His own dear team, he goeth forth.

p: Looking upon the loftier light above the darkness we have come To Surya, Deva.among the Devas, the light that is most excellent.

p: Rising this day, O rich in friends, ascending to the loftier heaven, Surya remove my heart's disease, take from me this my yellow hue.

p: To parrots and to starlings let us give away my yellowness, or this my yellowness let us transfer to Haritala trees.

p: With all his conquering vigour this Aditya hath gone up on high, giving my foe into mine hand: let me not be my foeman's prey.

hymns.title: HYMN LI. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: MAKE glad with songs that Ram whom many men invoke, worthy of songs of praise, indra, the sea of wealth. Whose gracious deeds for men spread like the heavens abroad: sing praise to him the Sage, most liberal for our good.

p: As aids the skilful Rbhus yearned to Indra strong to save, who fills mid-air, encompassed round with might, Rushing in rapture; and o’er Satakratu came the gladdening shout that urged him on to victory.

p: Thou hast disclosed the kine's stall for the Angirases, and made a way for Atri by a hundred doors. On Vimada thou hast bestowed both food and wealth, making thy bolt dance in  'theofferings fight.

p: Thou hast unclosed the prisons of the waters; thou hast in the mountain seized the treasure. rich in gifts. When thou hadst slain with might the dragon Vrtra Indra, didst raise the Sun in heaven for all to see.

p: With wondrous might thou blewest enchanter fiends away, with powers celestial those who called on thee in jest. Thou, hero-hearted, hast broken down Pipru's forts, and helped Rjisvan when the Dasyus were struck dead.

p: Thou savedst Kutsa when Susna was smitten down; to Atithigva gavest Sambara for a prey. E’en mighty Arbuda thou troddest under foot: thou from of old wast born to strike the Dasyus dead.

p: All power and might is closely gathered up in thee; thy bounteous spirit joys in drinking Soma juice. Known is the thunderbolt that lies within thine arms: rend off therewith all manly prowess of our foe.

p: Discern thou well Aryas and Dasyus; punishing the lawless give them up to him whose grass is strewn. Be thou  'theofferings stron encourager all these thy deeds are my delight at festivals.

p: Indra gives up the lawless to the pious man, destroying by the Strong Ones those who have no strength. Vamra when glorified conquered the gathered piles of the still waxing great one who would reach the heaven.

p: The might which Usana hath formed for thee with might rends in its greatness and with strength both worlds apart. O Hero-souled, the steeds of Vata, yoked by thought, have carried thee to fame while thou art filled with power.

p: When Indra hath rejoiced with Kavya Usana, he mounts his steeds who swerve wider and wider yet. The Strong hath loosed his bolt with the swift rush of rain, and he hath rent in pieces Susna's firm-built forts.

p: Thou mountest on thy car amid strong Soma draughts: Saryata brought thee those in which thou hast delight. Indra, when thou art pleased with men whose Soma flows thou risest to unchallenged glory in the sky.

p: To old Kaksivan, Soma-presser, skilled in song, O Indra, thou didst give the youthful Vrcaya. Thou, very wise, wast Mena, Vrsansva's child: those deeds of thine must all be told at Soma feasts.

p: The good man's refuge in his need is Indra, firm as a doorpost, praised among the Pajras. Indra alone is Lord of wealth, the Giver, lover of riches, chariots, kine, and horses.

p: To him the Mighty One, the self-resplendent, verily strong and great, this praise is uttered. May we and all the heroes, with the princes, be, in this fray, O Indra, in thy keeping.

hymns.title: HYMN LII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: I GLORIFY that Ram who finds the light of heaven, whose hundred nobly-natured ones go forth with him. With hymn. May I turn hither Indra to mine aid.the Car which like a strong steed hasteth to the call.

p: Like as a mountain on firm basis, unremoved, he, thousandfold protector, waxed in mighty strength, when Indra, joying in the draughts of Soma juice, forced the clouds, subduing Vrtra stayer of their flow.

p: For he stays e’en the stayers, spread o’er laden cloud, rooted in light, strengthened in rapture by the wise. Indra with thought, with skilled activity, I call, most liberal giver, for he sates him with the juice.

p: Whom those that flow in heaven on sacred grass, his own assistants, nobly-natured, fill full like the sea. Beside that Indra when he smote down Vrtra stood his helpers, straight in form, mighty, invincible.
