p: To him, as in wild joy he fought with him who stayed the rain, his helpers sped like swift streams down a slope, when Indra, thunder-armed, made bold by Soma draughts, as Trta cleaveth Vala's fences, cleft him through.

p: Splendour encompassed thee, forth shone thy warrior might: the rain-obstructer lay in mid-air's lowest deep, what time, O Indra, thou didst cast thy thunder down upon the jaws of Vritra hard to be restrained.

p: The hymns which magnify thee, indra, reach to thee even as water-brooks flow down and fill the lake. Tvastar gave yet more force to thine appropriate strength, and forged thy thunderbolt of overpowering might.

p: When, indra, thou whose power is linked with thy Bay Steeds hadst smitten Vrtra, causing floods to flow for man, Thou heldst in thine arms the metal thunderbolt, and settest in the heaven the Sun for all to see.

p: In fear they raised the lofty self-resplendent hymn, praise giving and effectual, leading up to heaven, when Indra's helpers fighting for the good of men, the Maruts, faithful to mankind, joyed in the light.

p: Then Heaven himself, the mighty, at that Dragon's roar reeled back in terror when, indra, thy thunderbolt In the wild joy of Soma had struck off with might the head of Vrtra, tyrant of the earth and heaven.

p: O Indra, were this earth extended forth tenfold, and men who dwell therein multiplied day by day, Still here thy conquering might, Maghavan, would be famed: it hath waxed vast as heaven in majesty and power.

p: Thou, bold of heart, in thine own native might, for help, upon the limit of this mid-air and of heaven, Hast made the earth to be the pattern of thy strength: embracing flood and light thou reachest to the sky.

p: Thou art the counterpart of earth, the Master of lofty heaven with all its mighty Heroes: Thou hast filled all the region with thy greatness: yea, of a truth there is none other like thee.

p: Whose amplitude the heaven and earth have not attained, whose bounds the waters of mid-air have never reached. Not, when in joy he fights the stayer of the rain: thou, and non else, hast made all things in order due.

p: The Maruts sang thy praise in this encounter, and in thee all the Deities delighted, what time thou, indra, with thy spiky weapon, thy deadly bolt, smotest the face of Vrtra.

hymns.title: HYMN LIII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: WE will present fair praise unto the Mighty One, our hymns to Indra in Vivasvan's dwelling-place; For he hath ne’er found wealth in those who seem to sleep: those who give wealth to men accept no paltry praise.

p: Giver of horses, indra, giver of kine, giver of barley, thou art Lord and guard of wealth: Man's helper from of old, not disappointing hope, Friend of our friends, to thee as such we sing this praise.

p: Indra, most splendid, powerful, rich in mighty deeds, this treasure. spread around is known to be thine own. Gather therefrom, O Conqueror, and bring to us: fail not the hope of him who loves and sings to thee.

p: Well pleased with these bright flames and with these Soma drops, take thou away our poverty with seeds and kine. With Indra scattering the Dasyu through these drops, freed from their hat. May we obtain abundant food.

p: Let us obtain, O Indra, plenteous wealth and food, with strength exceeding glorious, shining to the sky: May we obtain the Deva Providence, the strength of heroes, special source of cattle, rich in steeds.

p: These our libations strength-inspiring, Soma draughts, gladdened thee in the fight with Vrtra. Hero Lord, what time thou slewest for the singer with trimmed grass ten thousand Vrtras, thou resistless in thy might.

p: Thou goest on from fight to fight intrepidly, destroying castle after castle here with strength. Thou, indra, with thy friend who makes the foe bow down, slewest from far away the guileful Namuci.

p: Thou hast struck down in death Karanja, parnaya, in Atithigva's very glorious going forth. Unyielding, when Rjisvan compassed them with siege, thou hast conquered the hundred forts of Vangrida.

p: With all-outstripping chariot-wheel, O Indra, thou far-famed, hast overthrown the twice ten Kings of men, with sixty thousand nine-and-ninety followers, who came in arms to fight with friendless Susravas.

p: Thou hast protected Susravas with assist, and Turvayana with thine aid, O Indra. Thou madest Kutsa, Atithigva, Ayu, subject unto this King, the young, the mighty.

p: May we protected by the Devas hereafter remain thy very prosperous friends, O Indra. Thee we extol, enjoying through thy favour life long and joyful and with store of heroes.

hymns.title: HYMN LIV. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: URGE us not, Maghavan, to this distressful fight, for non. May comprehend the limit of thy strength. Thou with fierce shout hast made the woods and rivers roar.

p: Sing hymns of praise to Sakra, Lord of power and might; laud thou and magnify Indra who heareth thee, who with his daring might, a Bull exceeding strong in strength, maketh him master of the heaven and earth.

p: Sing forth to lofty Dyaus a strength-bestowing song, the Bold, whose resolute mind hath independent sway. High glory hath the Asura, compact of strength, drawn on by two Bay Steeds: a Bull, a Car is he.

p: The ridges of the lofty heaven thou madest shake; thou, daring, of thyself smotest through Sambara, when bold with gladdening juice, thou warredst with thy bolt, sharp and two-edged, against the banded sorcerers.

p: When with a roar that fills the woods, thou forcest down on wind's head the stores which Susna kept confined, who shall have power to stay thee firm and eager-souled from doing still this day what thou of old hast done?

p: Thou helpest Narya, Turvasa, and Yadu, and Vayya's son Turviti, Satakratu! Thou helpest horse and car in final battle thou breakest down the nine-and-ninety castles.

p: A hero-lord is he, King of a mighty folk, who offers free oblations and promotes the Law, who with a bounteous guerdon welcomes hymns of praise: for him flows down the abundant stream below the sky.

p: His power is matchless, matchless is his wisdom; chief, through their work, be some who drink the Soma, Those, indra, who increase the lordly power, the firm heroic strength of thee the Giver.

p: Therefore for thee are these abundant beakers Indra's drink, stone-pressed juices held in ladles. Quaff them and satisfy therewith thy longing; then fix thy mind upon bestowing treasure..

p: There darkness stood, the vault that stayed the waters’ flow: in Vrtra's hollow side the rain-cloud lay concealed. But Indra smote the rivers which the obstructer stayed, flood following after flood, down steep declivities.

p: So give us, indra, bliss-increasing glory give us great sway and strength that conquers people. Preserve our wealthy patrons, save our princes; vouchsafe us wealth and food with noble offspring.

hymns.title: HYMN LV. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: THOUGH e’en this heaven's wide space and earth have spread them out, nor heaven nor eart. May be in greatness Indra's match. Awful and very mighty, causing woe to men, he whets his thunderbolt for sharpness, as a bull.

p: Like as the watery ocean, so doth he receive the rivers spread on all sides in their ample width. He bears him like a bull to drink of Soma juice, and will, as Warrior from of old, be praised for might.

p: Thou swayest, indra, all kinds of great manly power, so as to bend, as’t were, even that famed mountain down. Foremost among the Devas is he through hero might, set in the van, the Strong One, for each arduous deed.

p: He only in the wood is praised by worshippers, when he shows forth to men his own fair Indra-power. A friendly Bull is he, a Bull to be desired when Maghavan auspiciously sends forth his voice.

p: Yet verily the Warrior in his vigorous strength stirreth up with his might great battles for mankind; And men have faith in Indra, the resplendent One, what time he hurleth down his bolt, his dart of death.

p: Though, fain for glory, and with strength increased on earth, he with great might destroys the dwellings made with art. He makes the lights of heaven shine forth secure, he bids, exceeding wise, the floods flow for his worshipper.

p: Drinker of Soma, let thy heart incline to give; bring thy Bays hitherward, O thou who hearest praise. Those charioteers of thine, best skilled to draw the rein, the rapid sunbeams, indra, lead thee not astray.

p: Thou bearest in both hands treasure. that never fails; the famed One in his body holds unvanquished might. O Indra, in thy members many powers abide, like wells surrounded by the ministering monks.

hymns.title: HYMN LVI. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: FOR this man's full libations held in ladles, he hath roused him, eager, as a horse to meet the mare. He stays his golden car, yoked with Bay Horses, swift,  which strengthens for great deeds.

p: To him the guidance-following songs of praise flow full, as those who seek gain go in company to the flood. To him the Lord of power, the holy synod's might, as to a hill, with speed, ascend the loving ones.

p: Victorious, great is he; in manly battle shines, unstained with dust, his might, as shines a mountain peak; Wherewith the iron one, fierce e’en against the strong, in rapture, fettered wily Sushna fast in bonds.

p: When strength the Deva, made more strong for help by thee, waits upon Indra as the Sun attends the Dawn, then he who with his might unflinching kills the gloom stirs up the dust aloft, with joy and triumphing.

p: When thou with might, upon the framework of the heaven, didst fix, across, air's region firmly, unremoved. In the light-winning war, indra, in rapturous joy, thou conquered Vrtra dead and broughtest floods of rain.

p: Thou with thy might didst grasp, the holder-up of heaven, thou who art mighty also in the seats of earth. Thou, gladdened by the juice, hast set the waters free, and broken Vrtra's stony fences through and through.

hymns.title: HYMN LVII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: To him most liberal, lofty Lord of lofty wealth, verily powerful and strong, I bring my hymn. Whose checkless bounty, as of waters down a slope, is spread abroad for all that live, to give them strength.

p: Now all this world, for worship, shall come after thee—the offerer's libations like floods to the depth, when the well-loved one seems to rest upon the hill, the thunderbolt of Indra, wrought of gold.

p: To him, most meet for lofty praise, now bring gifts with reverence in this rite, whose being, for renown, yea, indra-power and light, have been created, like bay steeds, to move with speed.

p: Thine, indra, praised by many, excellently rich! are we who trusting in thy help draw near to thee. Lover of praise, non else but thou receives our laud: as earth loves all her creatures, love thou this our hymn.

p: Great is thy power, O Indra, we are thine. Fulfil the wish of this thy worshipper. After thee lofty heaven hath measured out its strength: to thee and to thy power this earth hath bowed itself.

p: Thou, who hast thunder for thy weapon, with thy bolt hast shattered into pieces this broad massive cloud. Thou hast sent down the obstructed floods that the, may flow: thou hast, thine own forever, all victorious might.

hymns.title: HYMN LVIII. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: NE’ER waxeth faint the Immortal, Son of Strength, since he, the Herald, hath become Vivasvan's messenger. On paths most excellent he measured out mid-air: he with oblation calls to service of the Devas.

p: Never decaying, seizing his appropriate food, rapidly, eagerly through the dry wood he spreads. His back, as he is sprinkled, glistens like a horse: loud hath he roared and shouted like the heights of heaven?

p: Set high in place o’er all, Lord of riches, seated as High Monk; Hastening like a car to men, to those who live, the Deva without delay gives boons to be desired.

p: Urged by the wind be spreads through dry wood as he lists, armed with his tongues for sickles, with a mighty roar. Black is thy path, Agni, changeless, with glittering waves! When like a bull thou rushest eager to the trees.

p: With teeth of flame, wind-driven, through the wood he speeds, triumphant like a bull among the herd of cows, with bright strength roaming to the everlasting air: things fixed, things moving quake before him as he flies.

p: The Bhrgus established thee among mankind for men, like as a treasure., beauteous, easy to invoke; Thee, Agni, as a herald and choice-worthy guest, as an auspicious Friend to the Celestial Race.

p: Agni, the seven tongues', him whom the monks elect at solemn worship, the Herald, messenger of all the Vasus, I serve with dainty food, I ask for riches.

p: Grant, Son of Strength, thou rich in friends, a refuge without a flaw this day to us thy praisers. O Agni, Son of Strength, with forts of iron preserve thou from distress the man who lauds thee.

p: Be thou a refuge, Bright One, to the singer, a shelter, Bounteous Lord, to those who worship. Preserve the singer from distress, O Agni. May he, enriched with meditation, come soon and early.

hymns.title: HYMN LIX. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: THE other fires are, verily, thy branches; the Immortals all rejoice in thee, O Agni. Centre art thou, Vaisvanara, of the people, sustaining men like a deep-founded pillar.

p: The forehead of the sky, earth's centre, Agni became the messenger of earth and heaven. Vaisvanara, the Deities produced thee, a Deva, to be a light unto the Arya.

p: As in the Sun firm rays are set forever, treasure.s are in Vaisvanara, in Agni. Of all the riches in the hills, the waters, the herbs, among mankind, thou art the Sovran.

p: As the great World-halves, so are their Son's praises; skilled, as a man, to act, is he the Herald. Vaisvanara, celestial, truly mighty, most manly One, hath many a youthful consort.

p: Even the lofty heaven, O Jatavedas Vaisvanara, hath not attained thy greatness. Thou art the King of lands where men are settled, thou hast brought comfort to the Devas in battle.

p: Now will I tell the greatness of the Hero Agni Vaisvanara.

p: Vaisvanara, dwelling by his might with all men, far-shining, is lauded, excellent, with hundred praises.

hymns.title: HYMN LX. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: As ’twere Some goodly treasure. brought, as a gift, the glorious Monk, Banner of Offering, the good Protector, child of two births, the swiftly moving envoy.

p: Both Devas and men obey this Ruler's order, Devas who are worshipped, men who yearn and worship. As Monk he takes his seat ere break of morning, House-Lord, adorable with men, ordainer.

p: May our fair praise, heart-born, most recent, reach him whose tongue, e’en at his birth, is sweet as honey. Whome mortal monks, men, with their stron endeavour, supplied with dainty offerings, have created.

p: Good to mankind, the yearning Purifier hath among men been placed as Monk choice-worthy. May Agni be our Friend, Lord of the Household, protector of the riches in the dwelling.

p: O Agni, as the guardian Lord of richesdecking thee like a horse, the swift prizewinner. May he, enriched with meditation, come soon and early.

hymns.title: HYMN LXI. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: EVEN to him, swift, strong and high. exalted, I bring my song of praise as dainty offerings, My thought to him resistless, praise-deserving, prayers offered most especially to Indra.

p: Praise, like oblation, I present, and utter aloud my song, my fair hymn to the Victor. For Indra, who is Lord of old, the singers have decked their lauds with heart and mind and spirit.

p: To him then with my lips mine adoration, winning heaven's light, most excellent, I offer, to magnify with songs of invocation and with fair hymns the Lord, most bounteous Giver.

p: Even for him I frame a laud, as fashions the wright a chariot for the man who needs it. Praises to him who gladly hears our praises, a hymn well-formed, all-moving, to wise Indra.

p: So with my tongue I deck, to please that Indra, my hymn, as ’twere a horse, through love of glory, to reverence the Hero, bounteous Giver, famed far and wide, destroyer of the castles.

p: Even for him hath Tvastar forged the thunder, most deftly wrought, celestial, for the battle, Wherewith he reached the vital parts of Vrtra, striking-the vast, the mighty with the striker.

p: As soon as, at libations of his mother, great Visnu had drunk up the draught, he plundered. The dainty cates, the cooked mess; but One stronger transfixed the wild boar, shooting through the mountain.

p: To him, to Indra, Consorts of the Devas, wove praises. The mighty heaven and earth hath he encompassed: thy greatness heaven and earth, combined, exceed not.

p: Yea, of a truth, his magnitude surpasseth the magnitude of earth, mid-air, and heaven. Indra, approved by all men, self-resplendent, waxed in his home, loud-voiced and strong for battle.

p: Through his own strength Indra with bolt of thunder, he let the floods go free, like cows imprisoned, for glory, with a heart inclined to bounty.

p: The rivers played, through his impetuous splendour, since with his bolt he compassed them on all sides. Using his might and favouring him who worshipped, he made a ford.

p: Vast, with thine ample power, with eager movement cast thy bolt of thunder. Rend thou  with bolt oblique, that floods of rai. May follow.

p: Sing with new lauds his exploits wrought aforetime, the deeds of him, yea, him who moveth swiftly, when, hurling forth his weapons in the battle, he with impetuous wrath lays low the foemen.

p: When he, yea, he, comes forth the firm. Set mountains and the whole heaven and earth. Ever praising the protection of that dear Friend, gain quickly strength heroic.

p: Now unto him of these things hath been given what he who rules alone o’er much, electeth. Indra hath helped Etasa, Soma-presser, contending in the race of steeds with Surya.

p: Thus to thee, indra, yoker of Bay Coursers, the Gotamas have brought their prayers to please thee. Bestory upon us thought, decked with all beauty. May he, enriched with meditation, come soon and early.

hymns.title: HYMN LXII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: A gladdening laud we ponder to him who loveth song, exceeding mighty. Let us sing glory to the far-famed Hero who must be praised with fair hymns by the singer.

p: Unto the great bring ye great adoration, a chant with praise to him exceeding mighty, Through whom our sires, Angirases, singing praises and knowing well the places, found the cattle.

p: When Indra and the Angirases desired it, Sarama found provision for her offspring. Narasamsa cleft the mountain, found the cattle: the heroes shouted with the kine in triumph.

p: Mid shout, loud shout, and roar, with the Navagvas, seven singers, hast thou, heavenly, rent the mountain; Thou hast, with speeders, with Dasagvas, indra, Sakra, with thunder rent obstructive Vala.

p: Thou dispelled the darkness. Thou Indra, hast spread out the earth's high ridges, and firmly fixed the region under heaven.

p: This is the deed most worthy of all honour, the fairest marvel of the Wonder-Worker, that, nigh where heaven bends down, he made four rivers flow full with waves that carry down sweet water.

p: Unwearied, won with lauding hymns. In highest sky like Bhaga, he the doer of marvels set both Dames and earth and heaven.

p: Still born afresh in alternation Round heaven and earth from ancient time have travelled, Night with dark limbs, Dawn with limbs of splendour.

p: Rich in good actions, skilled in operation, the Son with might maintains his perfect friendship. Thou in the raw cows, black of hue or ruddy, storest the ripe milk glossy white in colour.

p: Their paths, of old connected, rest uninjured; they with great might preserve the immortal statutes. For many thousand holy works the Sisters wait on the haughty Lord like wives and matrons.

p: Thoughts ancient, seeking wealth, with adoration, with newest lauds have sped to thee, O Mighty. As yearning wives cleave to their yearning husband, so cleave our hymns to thee, O Lord most potent.

p: Strong Deva, the riches which thy hands have holden from days of old have perished not nor wasted. Splendid art thou, O Indra, wise, unbending: strengthen us with might, O Lord of Power.

p: O mighty Indra, Sure leader, yoker of the Tawny Coursers. May he, enriched with meditation, come soon and early.

hymns.title: HYMN LXIII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: THOU art the Mighty One; when born, O Indra, with power thou terrifiedst earth and heaven; When, in their fear of thee, all firm-set mountains and monstrous creatures shook like dust before thee.

p: When thy two wandering Bays thou drawest hither, thy praiser laid within thine arms the thunder, Wherewith, O Much-invoked, in will resistless, thou smitest foemen down and many a castle.

p: Faithful art thou, these thou defiest, indra; thou art the Rbhus' Lord, heroic, victor. Thou, by his side, for young and glorious Kutsa, with steed and car in battle slewest Susna,

p: That, as a friend, thou furtheredst, O Indra, when, Thunderer, strong in act, thou crushedst Vrtra; When. Hero great-souled, with easy conquest didst rend the Dasyus in their distant dwelling.

p: This doest thou, and art not harmed, O Indra, e’en in the anger of the strongest mortal. Lay thou the race-course open for our horses: as with a club, subdue, Thunder-armed! our foemen.

p: Hence men invoke thee, indra, in the tumult of battle, in the light-bestowing conflict. This aid of thine, O Deva like One, was ever to be implored in deeds of might in combat.

p: Warring for Purukutsa thou, O Indra, Thunder-armed! breakest down the seven castles; Easily, for Sudas, like grass didst rend them, and out of need, King, broughtest gain to Puru.

p: O Indra, Deva who movest round about us, feed us with varied food plenteous as water— Food wherewithal, O Hero, thou bestowest vigour itself to flow to us forever.

p: Prayers have been made by Gotamas, O Indra, addressed to thee, with laud for thy Bay Horses. Bring us in noble shape abundant riches. May he, enriched with meditation, come soon and early.

hymns.title: HYMN LXIV. Maruts.
hymns.text:
p: BRING for the manly host, wise and majestical, for the Maruts bring thou a pure gift. I deck my songs as one deft-handed, wise in mind prepares the water that hath power in solemn rites.

p: They spring to birth, the lofty Ones, the Bulls of Heaven, divine, free from spot and . purifiers, shining brightly even as suns, awful of form like giants, scattering rain-drops down.

p: Never growing old, they have waxed, even as mountains, irresistible. They make all beings tremble with their mighty strength, even the very strongest, both of earth and heaven.

p: With glittering ornaments they deck them forth for show; for beauty on their breasts they bind their chains of gold. The lances on their shoulders pound to pieces; they were born together, of themselves, the Men of Heaven.

p: Loud roarers, giving strength, they make the winds, they make the lightnings with their powers. The restless shakers drain the udders of the sky, and ever wandering round fill the earth full with milk.

p: The bounteous Maruts fill full the waters which avail in solemn rites. They lead, as ’twere, the Strong Horse forth, that he may rain: they milk the thundering, the never-failing spring.

p: Mighty, with wondrous power and marvellously bright, selfstrong like mountains, ye glide swiftly on your way. Like the wild elephants ye eat the forests up when ye assume your strength among the bright red flames.

p: Exceeding wise they roar like lions mightily, they, all-possessing, are beauteous as antelopes; Stirring the darkness with lances and spotted deer, combined as monks, with serpents' fury through their might.

p: Heroes who march in companies, befriending man, with serpents' ire through strength, ye greet the earth and heaven. Upon the seats, O Maruts, of your chariots, upon the cars stands lightning visible as light.

p: Lords of all riches, dwelling in the home of wealth, endowed with mighty vigour, singers loud of voice. Heroes, of powers infinite, armed with strong men's rings, the archers, they have laid the arrow on their arms.

p: They who with golden fellies make the rain increase drive forward the big clouds like wanderers on the way. Self-moving, brisk, unwearied, they o’erthrow the firm; the Maruts with bright lances make all things to reel.

p: The brisk, the bright, the worshipful, the active Ones. To the strong band of Maruts cleave for happiness, the chasers of the sky, impetuous, vigorous.

p: Maruts, the man whom ye have guarded with your help, he verily in strength surpasseth all mankind. Spoil with his steeds he gaineth, treasure. with his men; he winneth honourable strength and prospereth.

p: O Maruts, to the worshippers give glorious strength invincible in battle, brilliant, bringing wealth, prais worthy, known to all men. May we foster well, during a hundred winters, son and progeny.

p: Will ye then, O ye Maruts, grant us riches, durable, rich in men, defying onslaught. A hundred, thousandfold, ever increasing? May he, enriched with meditation, come soon and early.

hymns.title: HYMN LXV. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: ONE-MINDED, wise, they tracked thee like a thief lurking in dark cave with a stolen cow: Thee claiming worship, bearing it to Devas: there nigh to thee sate all the Holy Ones.

p: The Devas approached the ways of holy Law; there was a gathering vast as heaven itself. The waters feed with praise the growing Babe, born nobly in the womb, the seat of Law.

p: Like grateful food, like some wide dwelling place, like a fruit-bearing hill, a wholesome stream. Like a steed urged to run in swift career, rushing like Sindhu, wh. May check his course?

p: Kin as a brother to his sister floods, he eats the woods as a King eats the rich. When through the forest, urged by wind, he spreads, verily Agni shears the hair of earth.

p: Like a swan sitting in the floods he pants wisest in mind mid men he wakes at morn. A Sage like Soma, sprung from Law, he grew like some young creature., mighty, shining far.

hymns.title: HYMN LXVI. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: LIKE the Sun's glance, like wealth of varied sort, like breath which is the life, like one's own sonlike a swift bird, a cow who yields her milk, pure and refulgent to the wood he speeds.

p: He offers safety like a pleasant home, like ripened corn, the Conqueror of men. Like a Seer lauding, famed among the folk; like a steed friendly he vouchsafes us power.

p: With flame insatiate, like eternal might; caring for each one like a dame at home; Bright when he shines forth, whitish mid the folk, like a car, gold-decked, thundering to the fight.

p: He strikes with terror like a dart shot forth, e’en like an archer's arrow tipped with flame; Master of present and of future life, the maidens’ lover and the matrons’ Lord.

p: To him lead all your ways. May we attain the kindled Deva.as cows their home at eve. He drives the flames below as floods their swell: the rays rise up to the fair place of heaven.

hymns.title: HYMN LXVII. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: VICTORIOUS in the wood, Friend among men, ever he claims obedience as a King. Gracious like peace, blessing like mental power, Monk was he, offering-bearer, full of thought.

p: He, bearing in his hand all manly might, crouched in the cavern, struck the Devas with fear. Men filled with understanding find him there, when they have sting prayers formed within their heart.

p: He, like the Unborn, holds the broad earth up; and with effective utterance fixed the sky. O Agni, guard the spots which cattle love: thou, life of all, hast gone from lair to lair.

p: Whoso hath known him dwelling in his lair, and hath approached the stream of holy Law. They who release him, paying sacred rites.truly to such doth he announce great wealth.

p: He who grows mightily in herbs, within each fruitful mother and each babe she bears, Wise, life of all men, in the waters’ home.for him have sages built as ’twere a seat.

hymns.title: HYMN LXVIII. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: COMMINGLING, restless, he ascends the sky, unveiling nights and all that stands or moves, as he the sole Indu is preeminent in greatness among all these other Devas.

p: All men are joyful in thy power, O Deva, that living from the dry wood thou art born. All truly share thy Deva.ead while they keep, in their accustomed ways, eternal Law.

p: Strong is the thought of Law, the Law's behest; all works have they performed; he quickens all. Whoso will bring oblation, gifts to thee, to him, bethinking thee, vouchsafe thou wealth.

p: Seated as Monk with Manu's progeny, of all these treasure.s he alone is Lord. Men yearn for children to prolong their line, and are not disappointed in their hope.

p: Eagerly they who hear his word fulfil his wish as sons obey their sire's behest. He, rich in food, unbars his wealth like doors: he, the House-Friend, hath decked heaven's vault with stars.

hymns.title: HYMN LXIX. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: BRIGHT, splendid, like Dawn's lover, he hath filled the two joined worlds as with the light of heaven. When born, with might thou hast encompassed them: Father of Devas, and yet their Son wast thou.

p: Agni, the Sage, the humble, who discerns like the cow's udder, the sweet taste of foodlike a bliss-giver to be drawn to men, sits gracious in the middle of the house.

p: Born in the dwelling like a lovely son, pleased, like a strong steed, he bears on the folk. What time the men and I, with heroes, call. May Agni then gain all through Deva like power.

p: None breaks these holy laws of thine when thou hast granted audience to these chieftains here. This is thy boast, thou smotest with thy peers, and joined with heroes dravest off disgrace.

p: Like the Dawn's lover, spreading light, well-known as hued like morn. May he remember me. They, bearing of themselves, unbar the doors: they all ascend to the fair place of heaven.

hymns.title: HYMN LXX. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: MAY we, the pious, win much food by prayer. May Agni with fair light pervade each act. He the observer of the heavenly laws of Devas, and of the race of mortal man.

p: He who is germ of waters, germ of woods, germ of all things that move not and that move. To him even in the rock and in the house: Immortal One, he cares for all mankind.

p: Agni is Lord of riches for the man who serves him readily with sacred songs. Protect these beings thou with careful thought, knowing the races both of Devas and men.

p: Whom many dawns and nights, unlike, make strong, whom, born in Law, all things that move and stand. He hath been won. Herald who sits in light, making effectual all our holy works.

p: Thou settest value on our cows and woods: all shall bring tribute to us to the light. Men have served thee in many and sundry spots, parting, as ’twere, an aged father's wealth.

p: Like a brave archer, like one skilled and bold, a fierce avenger, so he shines in fight.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXI. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: LOVING the loving One, as wives their husband, the sisters of one home have urged him forward, Bright-coloured, even, as the cows love morning, dark, breaking forth to view, and redly beaming.

p: Our sires with lauds burst e’en the firm-set fortress, yea, the Angirases, with roar, the mountain. They made for us a way to reach high heaven, they found us day, light, day's sign, beams of morning.

p: They stablished order, made his service fruitful; then parting them among the longing faithful, Not thirsting after aught, they come, most active, while with sweet food the race of Devas they strengthen.

p: Since Matarisvan, far-diffused, hath stirred him, and he in every house grown bright and noble. He, Bhrgu-like I hath gone as his companion, as on commission to a greater Sovran.

p: When man poured juice to Heaven, the mighty Father, he knew and freed himself from close embracement. The archer boldly shot at him his arrow, and the Deva.threw his splendour on his Daughter.

p: Whoso, hath flames for thee within his dwelling, or brings the worship which thou lovest daily, Do thou of double might increase his substance. May he whom thou incitest meet with riches.

p: All offerings offerings wait on Agni as the Seven mighty Rivers seek the ocean. Not by our brethren was our food discovered: find with the Devas care for us, thou who knowest.

p: When light hath filled the Lord of men for increase, straight from the heaven descends the limpid moisture. Agni hath brought to light and filled with spirit the youthful host blameless and well providing.

p: He who like thought goes swiftly on his journey, the Sun, alone is ever Lord of riches. The Kings with fair hands, Varuna and Mitra, protect the precious nectar in our cattle.

p: O Agni, break not our ancestral friendship, Sage as thou art, endowed with deepest knowledge. Old age, like gathering cloud, impairs the body: before that evil be come nigh protect me.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXII. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: THOUGH holding many gifts for men, he humbleth the higher powers of each wise ordainer. Agni is now the treasure.-lord of treasure.s, forever granting all immortal bounties.

p: The Devas infallible all searching found not him, the dear Babe who still is round about us. Worn weary, following his track, devoted, they reached the lovely highest home of Agni.

p: Because with holy oil the pure Ones, Agni, served thee the very pure three autumn seasons, therefore they won them holy names for worship, and nobly born they dignified their bodies.

p: Making them known to spacious earth and heaven, the holy Ones revealed the powers of Rudra. The mortal band, discerning in the distance, found Agni standing in the loftiest station.

p: Nigh they approached, one-minded, with their spouses, kneeling to him adorable paid worship. Friend finding in his own friend's eye protection, they made their own the bodies which they chastened.

p: Soon as the holy beings had discovered the thrice-seven mystic things contained within thee, with these, one-minded, they preserve the Amrta: guard thou the life of all their plants and cattle.

p: Thou, Agni, knower of men's works, hast sent us good food in constant course for our subsistence: Thou deeply skilled in paths of Devas becamest an envoy never wearied, offering-bearer.

p: Knowing the Law, the seven strong floods from heaven, full of good thought, discerned the doors of riches. Sarama found the cattle's firm-built prison whereby the race of man is still supported.

p: They who approached all noble operations making a path that leads to life immortal, to be the Bird's support, the spacious mother, Aditi, and her great Sons stood in power.

p: When Devas immortal made both eyes of heaven, they gave to him the gift of beauteous glory. Now they flow forth like rivers set in motion: they knew the Red Steeds coming down, O Agni.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXIII. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: HE who gives food, like patrimonial riches and guides aright like some wise man's instruction, Loved like a guest who lies in pleasant lodging.may he, as Monk, prosper his servant's dwelling.

p: He who like Savitar the Deva, true-minded protecteth with his power. all acts of vigour, Truthful, like splendour, glorified by many, like breath joy-giving.all must strive to win him.

p: He who on earth dwells like a king surrounded by faithful friends, like a Deva.all-sustaininglike heroes who preside, who sit in safety: like as a blameless dame dear to her husband.

p: Thee, such, in settlements secure, O Agni, our men serve ever kindled in each dwelling. On him have they laid splendour in abundance: dear to all men, bearer be he of riches.

p: May thy rich worshippers win food, O Agni, and princes gain long life who bring oblation. May we get booty from our foe in battle, presenting to the Devas their share for glory.

p: The cows of holy law, sent us by Heaven, have swelled with laden udders, loudly lowing; Soliciting his favour, from a distance the rivers to the rock have flowed together.

p: Agni, with thee, soliciting thy favour, the holy Ones have gained glory in heaven. They made the Night and Dawn of different colours, and set the black and purple hues together.

p: May we and those who worship be the mortals whom thou, O Agni, leadest on to riches. Thou hast filled earth and heaven and air's mid-region, and followest the whole world like a shadow.

p: Aided by thee, O Agni. May we conquer steeds with steeds, men with men, heroes with heroes, Lords of the wealth transmitted by our fathers: an. May our princes live a hundred winters.

p: May these our hymns of praise, Agni, ordainer, be pleasant to thee in thy heart and spirit. May we have power to hold thy steeds of riches, laying on thee the Deva.sent gift of glory.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXIV. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: As forth to offering we go, a hymn to a hymn let us say, who hears us even when afar;

p: Who, from of old, in carnage, when the people gathered, hath preserved His household for the worshipper.

p: And let men say, Agni is born, e’en he who slayeth Vrtra, he Who winneth wealth in every fight.

p: Him in whose house an envoy thou lovest to taste his offered gifts, and strengthenest his offering,

p: Him, Angiras, thou Son of Strength, all men call happy in his Deva, His offerings, and his sacred grass.

p: Hitherward shalt thou bring these Devas to our laudation and to taste. These offered gifts, fair-shining One.

p: When, Agni, on thine embassage thou goest not a sound is heard of steed or straining of thy car.

p: Aided by thee uninjured, strong, one after other, goes he forth: Agni, the offerer forward steps.

p: And splendid strength, heroic, high, Agni, thou grantest from the Devas, Thou Deva, to him who offers gifts.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXV. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: ACCEPT our loudest-sounding hymn, food most delightful to the Devas, pouring our offerings in thy mouth.

p: Now, Agni, will we say to thee, O wisest and best Angiras, Our precious, much-availing prayer.

p: Who, Agni, is thy kin, of men? who is thy worthy worshipper? On whom dependent? who art thou?

p: The kinsman, Agni, of mankind, their well beloved Friend art thou, a friend whom friend. May supplicate.

p: Bring to us Mitra, Varuna, bring the Devas to mighty offering. Bring them, O Agni, to thine home.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXVI. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: Ho. May the mind draw nigh to please thee, Agni? What hymn of praise shall bring us greatest blessing? Or who hath gained thy power by offers? or with what mind shall we bring thee oblations?

p: Come hither, Agni, sit thee down as Hotar; be thou who never wast deceived our leader. May Heaven and Earth, the all-pervading, love thee: worship the Devas to win for us their favour.

p: Burn thou up all the Raksasas, O Agni; ward thou off curses from  'our offerings. Bring hither with his Bays the Lord of Soma: here is glad welcome for the Bounteous Giver.

p: Thou Monk with lip and voice that bring us children hast been invoked. Here with the Devas be seated. Thine is the task of Cleanser and Presenter: waken us, Wealth-bestower and Producer.

p: As with oblations of the priestly Manus thou worshippedst the Devas, a Sage with sages, So now, O truthfullest Invoker Agni, worship this day with joy-bestowing ladle.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXVII. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: How shall we pay oblation unto Agni? What hymn, Deva.oved, is said to him refulgent? Who, deathless, true to Law, mid men a herald, bringeth the Devas as best of offerers?

p: Bring him with reverence hither, most propitious in offers, true to Law, the herald; For Agni, when he seeks the Devas for mortals, knows them full well and worships them in spirit.

p: For he is mental power, a man, and perfect; he is the bringer, friend-like, of the wondrous. The pious Aryan tribes at offers address them first to him who doeth marvels.

p: May Agni, foe-destroyer, manliest Hero, accept with love our hymns and our devotion. May the liberal lords whose strength is strongest, urged by their riches, stir our thoughts with vigour.

p: Thus Agni Jatavedas, true to Order, hath by the priestly Gotamas been lauded. May he augment in them splendour and vigour: observant, as he lists, he gathers increase.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXVIII. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: O JATAVEDAS, keen and swift, we Gotamas with sacred son exalt thee for thy glories' sake.

p: Thee, as thou art, desiring wealth Gotama worships with his song: We laud thee for thy glories' sake.

p: As such, like Angiras we call on thee best winner of the spoil: We laud thee for thy glories' sake.

p: Thee, best of Vrtra conquerers, thee who shakest off our Dasyu foes: We laud thee for thy glories' sake.

p: A pleasant song to Agni we, sons of Rahugana, have sung: We laud thee for thy glories' sake.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXIX. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: HE in mid-air's expanse hath golden tresses; a raging serpent, like the rushing tempest: Purely refulgent, knowing well the morning; like honourable dames, true, active workers.

p: Thy well-winged flashes strengthen in their manner, when the black Bull hath bellowed round about us. With drops that bless and seem to smile he cometh: the waters fall, the clouds utter their thunder.

p: When he comes streaming with the milk of worship, conducting by directest paths of Order Aryaman, Mitra, Varuna, parijman fill the hide full where lies the nether press-stone.

p: O Agni, thou who art the lord of wealth in kine, thou Son of Strength, vouchsafe to us, O Jatavedas, high renown.

p: He, Agni, kindled, good and wise, must be exalted in our song: Shine, thou of many forms, shine radiantly on us.

p: O Agni, shining of thyself by night and when the morning breaks, Burn, thou whose teeth are sharp, against the Raksasas.

p: Adorable in all our rites, favour us, Agni, with thine aid, when the great hymn is chanted forth.

p: Bring to us ever-conquering wealth, wealth, Agni, worthy of our choice, in all our frays invincible.

p: Give us, O Agni, through thy grace wealth that supporteth all our life, Thy favour so that we may live.

p: O Gotama, desiring bliss present thy songs composed with care To Agni of the pointed flames.

p: May the man fall, O Agni, who near or afar assaileth us: Do thou increase and prosper us.

p: Keen and swift Agni, thousand-eyed, chaseth the Raksasas afar: He singeth, herald meet for lauds.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXX. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: THUS in the Soma, in wild joy the Brahman hath exalted thee: Thou, mightiest thunder-armed, hast driven by force the Dragon from the earth, lauding thine own imperial sway.

p: The mighty flowing Soma-draught, brought by the Hawk, hath gladdened thee, that in thy strength, O Thunderer, thou hast struck down Vrtra from the floods, lauding thine own imperial sway.

p: Go forward, meet the foe, be bold; thy bolt of thunder is not checked. Manliness, indra, is thy might: stay Vrtra, make the waters thine, lauding thine own imperial sway.

p: Thou conquered Vrtra from the earth, smotest him, indra, from the sky. Let these life-fostering waters flow attended by the Marut host, lauding thine own imperial sway.

p: The wrathful Indra with his bolt of thunder rushing on the foe, Smote fierce on trembling Vrtra's back, and loosed the waters free to run, lauding his own imperial sway.

p: With hundred-jointed thunderbolt Indra hath struck him on the back, and, while rejoicing in the juice, seeketh prosperity for friends, lauding his own imperial sway.

p: Indra, unconquered might is thine, Thunderer, Caster of the Stone; For thou with thy surpassing power smotest to death the guileful beast, lauding thine own imperial sway.

p: Far over ninety spacious floods thy thunderbolts were cast abroad: Great, indra, is thy hero might, and strength is seated in thine arms, lauding thine own imperial sway.

p: Laud him a thousand all at once, shout twenty forth the hymn of praise. Hundreds have sung aloud to him, to Indra hath the prayer been raised, lauding his own imperial sway.

p: Indra hath smitten down the power of Vrtra.might with stronger might. This was his manly exploit, he slew Vrtra and let loose the floods, lauding his own imperial sway.

p: Yea, even this great Pair of Worlds trembled in terror at thy wrath, when, indra, Thunderer, Marut-girt, thou slewest Vrtra in thy strength, lauding thine own imperial sway.

p: But Vrtra scared not Indra with his shaking or his thunder roar. On him that iron thunderbolt fell fiercely with its thousand points, lauding his own imperial sway.

p: When with the thunder thou didst make thy dart and Vrtra meet in war, Thy might, O Indra, fain to subdue the Dragon, was set firm in heaven, lauding thine own imperial sway.

p: When at thy shout, O Thunder-armed, each thing both fixed and moving shook, E’en Tvastar trembled at thy wrath and quaked with fear because of thee, lauding thine own imperial sway.

p: There is not, in our knowledge, one who passeth Indra in his strength: In him the Deities have stored manliness, insight, power and might, lauding his own imperial sway.

p: Still as of old, whatever rite Atharvan, Manus sire of all, Dadhyach performed, their prayer and praise united in that Indra meet, lauding his own imperial sway.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXI. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: THE men have lifted Indra up, the Vrtra slayer, to joy and strength: Him, verily, we invocate in battles whether great or small: be he our aid in deeds of might.

p: Thou. Hero, art a warrior, thou art giver of abundant spoil. Strengthening e’en the feeble, thou aidest  'the offeringr, thou givest the offerer ample wealth.

p: When war and battles are on foot, booty is laid before the bold. Yoke thou thy wildly-rushing Bays. Whom wilt thou subdue and whom enrich? Do thou, O Indra, make us rich.

p: Mighty through wisdom, as he lists, terrible, he hath waxed in strength. Lord of Bay Steeds, strong-jawed, sublime, he in joined hands for glory's sake hath grasped his iron thunderbolt.

p: He filled the earthly atmosphere and pressed against the lights in heaven. None like thee ever hath been born, none, indra, will be born like thee. Thou hast waxed mighty over all.

p: May he who to the offerer gives the foeman's man-sustaining food, may Indra lend his aid to us. Deal forth—abundant is thy wealth—that in thy bounty . May share.

p: He, righteous-hearted, at each time of rapture gives us herds of kine. Gather in both thy hands for us treasure.s of many hundred sorts. Sharpen thou us, and bring us wealth.

p: Refresh thee. Hero, with the for bounty and for strength. We know thee Lord of ample store, to thee have sent our hearts' desires: be therefore our Protector thou.

p: These people, indra, keep for thee all that is worthy of thy choice. Discover thou, as Lord, the wealth of men who offer up no gifts: bring thou to us this wealth of theirs.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: GRACIOUSLY listen to our songs, Maghavan, be not negligent. As thou hast made us full of joy and lettest us solicit thee, now, indra, yoke thy two Bay Steeds.

p: Well have they eaten and rejoiced; the friends have risen and passed away. The sages luminous in themselves have. praised thee with their latest hymn. Now, indra, yoke thy two Bay Steeds.

p: Maghavan, we will reverence thee who art so fair to look upon. Thus praised, according to our wish come now with richly laden car. Now, indra, yoke thy two Bay Steeds.

p: He will in very truth ascend the powerful car that finds the kine, who thinks upon the well-filled bowl, the Tawny Coursers' harnesser. Now, indra, yoke thy two Bay Steeds.

p: Let, Lord of Hundred Powers, thy Steeds be harnessed on the right and left. Therewith in rapture of the juice, draw near to thy beloved Spouse. Now, indra, yoke thy two Bay Steeds.

p: With holy prayer I yoke thy long-maned pair of Bays: come hitherward; thou holdest them in both thy hands. The stirring draughts of have made thee glad: thou, Thunderer, hast rejoiced with Pusan and thy Spouse.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXIII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: INDRA, the mortal man well guarded by thine aid goes foremost in the wealth of horses and of kine. With amplest wealth thou fillest him, as round about the waters clearly seen afar fill Sindhu full.

p: The heavenly Waters come not nigh the priestly bowl: they but look down and see how far mid-air is spread: The Deities conduct the pious man to them: like suitors they delight in him who loveth prayer.

p: Prais worthy blessing hast thou laid upon the pair who with uplifted ladle serve thee, man and wife. Unchecked he dwells and prospers in thy law: thy power brings blessing to  'the offeringr pouring gifts.

p: First the Angirases won themselves vital power, whose fires were kindled through good deeds and offering. The men together found the Pani's hoarded wealth, the cattle, and the wealth in horses and in kine.

p: Atharvan first by offers laid the paths then, guardian of the Law, sprang up the loving Sun. Usana Kavya straightway hither drove the kine. Let us with offerings honour Yama's deathless birth.

p: When sacred grass is trimmed to aid the auspicious work, or the hymn makes its voice of praise sound to the sky. Where the stone rings as ’twere a singer skilled in laud.Indra in truth delights when these come near to him.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXIV. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: The Soma hath been pressed for thee, O Indra; mightiest, bold One, come. May Indra-vigour fill thee full, as the Sun fills mid-air with rays.

p: His pair of Tawny Coursers bring Indra of unresisted might Hither to Rsis’ songs of praise and offering performed by men.

p: Slayer of Vrtra, mount thy car; thy Bay Steeds have been yoked by prayer. May, with its voice, the pressing-stone draw thine attention hitherward.

p: This poured libation, indra, drink, immortal, gladdening, excellent. Streams of the bright have flowed to thee here at the seat of holy Law.

p: Sing glory now to Indra, say to him your solemn eulogies. The drops poured forth have made him glad: pay reverence to his might supreme.

p: When, indra, thou dost yoke thy Steeds, there is no better charioteer: None hath surpassed thee in thy might, none with good steeds o’ertaken thee.

p: He who alone bestoweth on mortal man who offereth gifts, the ruler of resistless power, is Indra, sure.

p: When will he trample, like a weed, the man who hath no gift for him? When, verily, will Indra hear our songs of praise?

p: He who with Soma juice prepared amid the many honours thee. Verily Indra gains thereby tremendous might.

p: The juice of Soma thus diffused, sweet to the taste, the bright cows drink, who for the sake of splendour close to mighty Indra's side rejoice, good in their own supremacy.

p: Craving his touch the dappled kine mingle the Soma with their milk. The milch-kine dear to Indra send forth his death-dealing thunderbolt, good in their own supremacy.

p: With veneration, passing wise, honouring his victorious might, they follow close his many laws to win them due preeminence, good in their own supremacy.

p: With bones of Dadhyach for his arms, indra, resistless in attack, Struck nine-and-ninety Vrtras dead.

p: He, searching for the horse's head, removed among the mountains, found At Saryanavan what he sought.

p: Then verily they recognized the essential form of Tvastar's Bull. Here in the mansion of the Moon.

p: Who yokes to-day unto the pole of Order the strong and passionate steers of checkless spirit, with shaft-armed mouths, heart-piercing, health-bestowing? Long shall he live who richly pays their service.

p: Who fleeth forth? who suffereth? who feareth? Who knoweth Indra present, indra near us? Who sendeth benediction on his offspring, his household, wealth and person, and the People?

p: Who with poured oil and offering honours Agni, with ladle worships at appointed seasons? To whom to the Devas bring oblation quickly? What offerer, Deva.favoured, knows him thoroughly?

p: Thou as a Deva, O Mightiest, verily blessest mortal man. O Maghavan, there is no comforter but thou: Indra, I speak my words to thee.

p: Let not thy bounteous gifts, let not thy saving help fail us, good Lord, at any time; And measure out to us, thou lover of mankind, all riches hitherward from men.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXV. Maruts.
hymns.text:
p: THEY who are glancing forth, like women, on their way, doers of mighty deeds, swift racers, Rudra's Sons, the Maruts have made heaven and earth increase and grow: in offers they delight, the strong and wild.

p: Grown to their perfect strength greatness have they attained; the Rudras have established their abode in heaven. Singing their song of praise and generating might, they have put glory on, the Sons whom Prsni bare.

p: When, Children of the Cow, they shine in bright attire, and on their fair limbs lay their golden ornaments, they drive away each adversary from their path, and, following their traces, fatness floweth down,

p: When, mighty Warriors, ye who glitter with your spears, o’erthrowing with your strength e’en what is ne’er o’erthrown, when, O ye Maruts, ye the host that send the rain, had harnessed to your cars the thought-fleet spotted deer.

p: When ye have harnessed to your cars the spotted deer, urging the thunderbolt, O Maruts, to the fray, forth rush the torrents of the dark red stormy cloud, and moisten, like a skin, the earth with water-floods.

p: Let your swift-gliding coursers bear you hitherward with their fleet pinions. Come ye forward with your arms. Sit on the grass; a wide seat hath been made for you: delight yourselves, O Maruts, in the pleasant food.

p: Strong in their native strength to greatness have they grown, stepped to the firmament and made their dwelling wide. When Visnu saved the Soma bringing wild delight, the Maruts sate like birds on their dear holy grass.

p: In sooth like heroes fain for fight they rush about, like combatants fame-seeking have they striven in war. Before the Maruts every creature. is afraid: the men are like to Kings, terrible to behold.

p: When Tvastar deft of hand had turned the thunderbolt, golden, with thousand edges, fashioned more skilfully, indra received it to perform heroic deeds. Vrtra he slew, and forced the flood of water forth.

p: They with their vigorous strength pushed the well up on high, and clove the cloud in twain though it was passing strong. The Maruts, bounteous Givers, sending forth their voice, in the wild joy of Soma wrought their glorious deeds.

p: They drave the cloud transverse directed hitherward, and poured the fountain forth for thirsting Gotama. Shining with varied light they come to him with help: they with their might fulfilled the longing of the sage.

p: The shelters which ye have for him who lauds you, bestow them threefold on the man who offers. Extend the same boons unto us, ye Maruts. Give us, O Heroes, wealth with noble offspring.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXVI. Maruts.
hymns.text:
p: THE best of guardians hath that man within whose dwelling place ye drink, O Maruts, giants of the sky.

p: Honoured with offering or with the worship of the sages’ hymns, O Maruts, listen to the call.

p: Yea, the strong man to whom ye have vouchsafed to give a sage, shall move Into a stable rich in kine.

p: Upon this hero's sacred grass Soma is poured in daily rites: Praise and delight are sung aloud.

p: Let the strong Maruts hear him, him surpassing all men: strength be his That reaches even to the Sun.

p: For, through the swift Devas’ loving help, in many an autumn, Maruts, we Have offered up  'our offering.

p: Fortunate shall that mortal be, O Maruts most adorable, whose offerings ye bear away.

p: O Heroes truly strong, ye know the toil of him who sings your praise, the heart's desire of him who loves.

p: O ye of true strength, make this thing manifest by your greatness: strike The demon with your thunderbolt.

p: Conceal the horrid darkness, drive far from us each devouring fiend. Create the light for which we long.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXVII. Maruts.
hymns.text:
p: LOUD Singers, never humbled, active, full of strength, immovable, impetuous, manliest, best-beloved, they have displayed themselves with glittering ornaments, a few in number only, like the heavens with stars.

p: When, Maruts, on the steeps ye pile the moving cloud, ye are like birds on whatsoever path it be. Clouds everywhere shed forth the rain upon your cars. Drop fatness, honey-hued, for him who sings your praise.

p: Earth at their racings trembles as if weak and worn, when on their ways they yoke their cars for victory. They, sportive, loudly roaring, armed with glittering spears, shakers of all, themselves admire their mightiness.

p: Self-moving is that youthful band, with spotted steeds; thus it hath lordly sway, endued with power and might. Truthful art thou, and blameless, searcher out of sin: so thou, Strong Host, wilt be protector of this prayer.

p: We speak by our descent from our primeval Sire; our tongue, when we behold the Soma, stirs itself. When, shouting, they had joined Indra in toil of fight, then only they obtained their offerings names.

p: Splendours they gained for glory, they who wear bright rings; rays they obtained, and men to celebrate their praise. Armed with their swords, impetuous and fearing naught, they have possessed the Maruts’ own beloved home.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXVIII. Maruts.
hymns.text:
p: COME hither, Maruts, on your lightning laden cars, sounding with sweet songs, armed with lances, winged with steeds. Fly unto us with noblest food, like birds, O ye of mighty power.

p: With their red-hued or, haply, tawny coursers which speed their chariots on, they come for glory. Brilliant like gold is he who holds the thunder. Earth have they smitten with the chariot's felly.

p: For beauty ye have swords upon your bodies. As they stir woods s. May they stir our spirits. For your sake, O ye Maruts very mighty and well-born, have they set the stone, in motion.

p: The days went round you and came back O yearners, back, to this prayer and to this solemn worship. The Gotamas making their prayer with singing have pushed the well's lid up to drink the water.

p: No hymn way ever known like this aforetime which Gotama sang forth for you, O Maruts, what time upon your golden wheels he s w you, wild boars rushing about with tusks of iron.

p: To you this freshening draught of Soma rusheth, O Maruts, like the voice of one who prayeth. It rusheth freely from our hands as these libations wont to flow.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXIX, Devas.
hymns.text:
p: MAY powers auspicious come to us from every side, never deceived, unhindered, and victorious, that the Devas eve. May be with us for our gain, our guardians day by day unceasing in their care.

p: May the auspicious favour of the Devas be ours, on us descend the bounty of the righteous Devas. The friendship of the Devas have we devoutly sought: s. May the Devas extend our life that we may live.

p: We call them hither with a hymn of olden time, Bhaga, the friendly Daksa, Mitra, Aditi, Aryaman, Varuna, Soma, the Asvins. May Sarasvati, auspicious, grant felicity.

p: May the Wind waft to us that pleasant medicine. May Earth our Mother give it, and our Father Heaven, and the joy-giving stones that press the Soma's juice. Asvins. May ye, for whom our spirits long, hear this.

p: Him we invoke for aid who reigns supreme, the Lord of all that stands or moves, inspirer of the soul, that Pusa. May promote the increase of our wealth, our keeper and our guard infallible for our good.

p: Illustrious far and wide. May Indra prosper us. May Pusan prosper us, the Master of all wealth. May Tarksya with uninjured fellies prosper us: Narasamsa vouchsafe to us prosperity.

p: The Maruts, Sons of Prsni, borne by spotted steeds, moving in glory, oft visiting holy rites, Sages whose tongue is Agni, brilliant as the Sun.hither let all the Devas for our protection come.

p: Devas. May we with our ears listen to what is good, and with our eyes see what is good, ye Holy Ones. With limbs and bodies fir. May we extolling you attain the term of life appointed by the Devas.

p: A hundred autumns stand before us, O ye Devas, within whose space ye bring our bodies to decay; Within whose space our sons become fathers in turn. Break ye not in the midst our course of fleeting life.

p: Aditi is the heaven, Aditi is mid-air, Aditi is the Mother and the Sire and Son. Aditi is all Devas, Aditi five-classed men, Aditi all that hath been born and shall be born.

hymns.title: HYMN XC, Devas.
hymns.text:
p: MAY Varuna with guidance straight, and Mitra lead us, he who knows, and Aryaman in accord with Devas.

p: For they are dealers forth of wealth, and, not deluded, with their might Guard evermore the holy laws.

p: Shelte. May they vouchsafe to us, Immortal Devas to mortal men, Chasing our enemies away.

p: May they mark out our paths to bliss, indra, the Maruts, pusan, and Bhaga, the Devas to be adored.

p: Yea, pusan, Visnu, ye who run your course, enrich our hymns with kine; Bless us with all prosperity.

p: The winds waft sweets, the rivers pour sweets for the man who keeps the Law May the plants be sweet for us.

p: Sweet be the night and sweet the dawns, sweet the terrestrial atmosphere; Sweet be our Father Heaven to us.

p: May the tall tree be full of sweets for us, and full of sweets the Sun: May our milch-kine be sweet for us.

p: Be Mitra gracious unto us, and Varuna and Aryaman: Indra, Narasamsa be kind, and Visnu of the mighty stride.

hymns.title: HYMN XCI. Soma.
hymns.text:
p: Thou, Soma, art preeminent for wisdom; along the straightest path thou art our leader. Our wise forefathers by thy guidance, Indu, dealt out among the Devas their share of treasure..

p: Thou by thine insight art most wise, O Soma, strong by thine energies and all possessing, Mighty art thou by all thy powers and greatness, by glories art thou glorious, guide of mortals.

p: Thine are King Varuna's eternal statutes, lofty and deep, O Soma, is thy glory. All-pure art thou like Mitra the beloved, adorable, like Aryaman, O Soma.

p: With all thy glories on the earth, in heaven, on mountains, in the plants, and in the waters. With all of these, well-pleased and not in anger, accept, O royal Soma, our oblations.

p: Thou, Soma, art the Lord of heroes, King, yea, Vrtra conquerer thou: Thou art auspicious energy.

p: And, Soma, let it be thy wish that we may live an. May not die: Praise-loving Lord of plants art thou.

p: To him who keeps the law, both old and young, thou givest happiness, and energy that h. May live.

p: Guard us, King Soma, on all sides from him who threatens us: never let The friend of one like thee be harmed.

p: With those delightful aids which thou hast, Soma, for the worshipper. Even with those protect thou us.

p: Accepting this  'our offering and this our praise, O Soma, come, and be thou nigh to prosper us.

p: Well-skilled in speech we magnify thee, Soma, with our sacred songs: Come thou to us, most gracious One.

p: Enricher, healer of disease, wealth-finder, prospering our store, be, Soma, a good Friend to us.

p: Soma, be happy in our heart, as milch-kine in the grassy meads, as a young man in his own house.

p: O Soma, Deva, the mortal man who in thy friendship hath delighthim doth the mighty Sage befriend.

p: Save us from slanderous reproach, keep us., O Soma, from distress: Be unto us a gracious Friend.

p: Soma, wax great. From every sid. May vigorous powers unite in thee: Be in the gathering-place of strength.

p: Wax, O most gladdening Soma, great through all thy rays of light, and be A Friend of most illustrious fame to prosper us.

p: In thee be juicy nutriments united, and powers and mighty foe-subduing vigour, waxing to immortality, O Soma: win highest glories for thyself in heaven.

p: Such of thy glories as with poured oblations men honour. May they all invest our worship. Wealth-giver, furtherer with troops of heroes, sparing the brave, come, Soma, to our houses.

p: To him who worships Soma gives the MilchCow, a fleet steed and a man of active knowledge, Skilled in home duties, meet for holy synod, for council meet, a glory to his father.

p: Invincible in fight, saver in battles, guard of our camp, winner of light and water, Born amid hymns, well-housed, exceeding famous, victor, in thee will we rejoice, O Soma.

p: These herbs, these milch-kine, and these running waters, all these, O Soma, thou hast generated. The spacious firmament hast thou expanded, and with the light thou hast dispelled the darkness.

p: Do thou, Deva.Soma, with thy Deva like spirit, victorious, win for us a share of riches. Let none prevent thee: thou art Lord of valour. Provide for both sides in the fray for booty.

hymns.title: HYMN XCII. Dawn.
hymns.text:
p: THESE Dawns have raised their banner; in the eastern half of the mid-air they spread abroad their shining light. Like heroes who prepare their weapons for the war, onward they come bright red in hue, the Mother Cows.

p: Readily have the purple beams of light shot up; the Red Cows have they harnessed, easy to be yoked. The Dawns have brought distinct perception as before: red-hued, they have attained their fulgent brilliancy.

p: They sing their song like women active in their tasks, along their common path hither from far away, Bringing refreshment to the liberal devotee, yea, all things to the worshipper who pours the juice.

p: She, like a dancer, puts her broidered garments on: as a cow yields her udder so she bares her breast. Creating light for all the world of life, the Dawn hath laid the darkness open as the cows their stall.

p: We have beheld the brightness of her shining; it spreads and drives away the darksome monster. Like tints that deck the Post at offers. Heaven's Daughter hath attained her wondrous splendour.

p: We have o’erpast the limit of this darkness; Dawn breaking forth again brings clear perception. She like a flatterer smiles in light for glory, and fair of face hath wakened to rejoice us.

p: The Gotamas have praised Heaven's radiant Daughter, the leader of the charm of pleasant voices. Dawn, thou conferrest on us strength with offspring and men, conspicuous with kine and horses.

p: O thou who shinest forth in wondrous glory, urged onward by thy strength, auspicious Lady, Dawn. May I gain that wealth, renowned and ample, in brave sons, troops of slaves, far-famed for horses.

p: Bending her looks on all the world, the Deva shines, widely spreading with her bright eye wes ward. Waking to motion every living creature., she understands the voice of each adorer.

p: Ancient of days, again again born newly, decking her beauty with the self-same raiment. The Deva wastes away the life of mortals, like a skilled hunter cutting birds in pieces.

p: She hath appeared discovering heaven's borders: to the far distance she drives off her Sister. Diminishing the days of human creatures, the Lady shines with all her lover's splendour.

p: The bright, the blessed One shines forth extending her rays like kine, as a flood rolls his waters. Never transgressing the divine commandments, she is beheld visible with the sunbeams.

p: O Dawn enriched with ample wealth, bestow on us the wondrous gift Wherewith we may support children and children's sons.

p: Thou radiant mover of sweet sounds, with wealth of horses and of kine Shine thou on us this day, O Dawn auspiciously.

p: O Dawn enriched with holy rites, yoke to thy car thy purple steeds, and then bring thou unto us all felicities.

p: O Asvins wonderful in act, do ye unanimous direct Your chariot to our home wealthy in kine and gold.

p: Ye who brought down the hymn from heaven, a light that giveth light to man, Do ye, O Asvins, bring strength hither unto us.

p: Hithe, may they who wake at dawn bring, to drink Soma both the Devas Health-givers Wonder-Workers, borne on paths of gold.

hymns.title: HYMN XCIII. Agni-Soma.
hymns.text:
p: AGNI and Soma, mighty Pair, graciously hearken to my call, accept in friendly wise my hymn, and prosper him who offers gifts.

p: The man who honours you to-day, Agni and Soma, with this hymn, bestow on him heroic strength, increase of kine, and noble steeds.

p: The man who offers holy oil and burnt oblations unto you, Agni and Soma, shall enjoy great strength, with offspring, all his life.

p: Agni and Soma, famed is that your. prowess wherewith ye stole the kine, his food, from Pani. Ye caused the brood of Brsaya to perish; ye found the light, the single light for many.

p: Agni and Soma, joined in operation ye have set up the shining lights in heaven. From curse and from reproach, Agni and Soma, ye freed the rivers that were bound in fetters.

p: One of you Matarisvan brought from heaven, the Falcon rent the other from the mountain. Strengthened by holy prayer Agni and Soma have made us ample room for sacrificing.

p: Taste, Agni, Soma, this prepared oblation; accept it, MightyOnes, and let it please you. Vouchsafe us good protection and kind favour: grant to  'the offeringr health and riches.

p: Whoso with oil and poured oblation honours, with devoted heart, Agni and Soma. Protect his offering, preserve him from distress, grant to  'the offeringr great felicity.

p: Invoked together, mates in wealth, Agni-Soma, accept our hymns: Together be among the Devas.

p: Agni and Soma, unto him who worships you with holy oil Shine forth an ample recompense.

p: Agni and Soma, be ye pleased with these oblations brought to you, and come, together, nigh to us.

p: Agni and Soma, cherish well our horses, and let our cows be fat who yield oblations. Grant power to us and to our wealthy patrons, and cause our holy rites to be successful.

hymns.title: HYMN XCIV. Agni
hymns.text:
p: FOR Jatavedas worthy of our praise will we frame with our mind this eulogy as ’twere a car. For good, in his assembly, is this care of ours. Let us not, in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

p: The man for whom thou offerst prospereth, dwelleth without a foe, gaineth heroic might. He waxeth strong, distress never approacheth him. Let us not, in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

p: May we have power to kindle thee. Fulfil our thoughts. In thee the Devas eat the presented offering, Bring hither the Adityas, for we long for them. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

p: We will bring fuel and prepare burnt offerings, reminding thee at each successive festival. Fulfil our thought that so we may prolong our lives. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

p: His ministers move forth, the guardians of the folk, protecting quadruped and biped with their rays. Mighty art thou, the wondrous herald of the Dawn. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

p: Thou art Presenter and the chief Invoker, thou Director, purifier, great High Monk by birth. Knowing all priestly work thou perfectest it, Sage. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

p: Lovely of form art thou, alike on every side; though far, thou shinest brightly as if close at hand. O Deva, thou seest through even the dark of night. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

p: Devas, foremost be his car who pours libations out, and let our hymn prevail o’er evil-hearted men. Attend to this our speech and make it prosper well. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

p: Smite with thy weapons those of evil speech and thought, devouring demons, whether near or tar away. Then to the singer give free way for offering. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

p: When to thy chariot thou hadst yoked two red steeds and two ruddy steeds, wind-sped, thy roar was like a bull's. Thou with smoke-bannered flame attackest forest trees. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

p: Then at thy roar the very birds are terrified, when, eating-up the grass, thy sparks fly forth abroad. Then is it easy for thee and thy car to pass. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

p: He hath the Power to soothe Mitra and Varuna: wonderful is the Maruts’ wrath when they descend. Be gracious; let their hearts he turned to us again. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

p: Thou art a Deva, thou art the wondrous Friend of Devas, the Vasu of the Vasus, fair in offering. Under, thine own most wide protection. May we dwell. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

p: This is thy grace that, kindled in thine own abode, invoked with Soma thou soundest forth most benign, Thou givest wealth and treasure. to the worshipper. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

p: To whom thou, Lord of goodly riches, grantest freedom from every sin with perfect wholeness, whom with good strength thou quickenest, with children and wealth—may we be they, Eternal Being.

p: Such, Agni, thou who knowest all good fortune, Deva, lengthen here the days of our existence. This prayer of our. May Varuna grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

hymns.title: HYMN XCV. Agni
hymns.text:
p: To fair goals travel Two unlike in semblance: each in succession nourishes an infant. One bears a Deva like Babe of golden colour; bright and fair-shining, is he with the other.

p: Tvastar's ten daughters, vigilant and youthful, produced this Infant borne to sundry quarters. They bear around him whose long flames are pointed, fulgent among mankind with native splendour.

p:  Three several places of his birth they honour, in mid-air, in the heaven, and in the waters. Governing in the east of earthly regions, the seasons hath he stablished in their order.

p: Who of you knows this secret One? The Infant by his own nature hath brought forth his Mothers. The germ of many, from the waters' bosom he goes forth, wise and great, of Deva like nature.

p: Visible, fair, he grows in native brightness uplifted in the lap of waving waters. When he was born both Tvastar's worlds were frightened: they turn to him and reverence the Lion.

p: The Two auspicious Ones, like women, tend him: like lowing cows they seek him in their manner. He is the Lord of Might among the mighty; him, on the right, they balm with their oblations.

p: Like Savitar his arms with might he stretches; awful, he strives grasping the world's two borders. He forces out from all a brilliant vesture, yea, from his Mothers draws he forth new raiment.

p: He makes him a most noble form of splendour, decking him in his home with milk and waters. The Sage adorns the depths of air with wisdom: this is the meeting where the Devas are worshipped.

p: Wide through the firmament spreads forth triumphant the far-resplendent strength of thee the Mighty. Kindled by us do thou preserve us, Agni, with all thy self-bright undiminished assists.

p: In dry spots he makes stream, and course, and torrent, and inundates the earth with floods that glisten. All ancient things within his maw he gathers, and moves among the new fresh-sprouting grasses.

p: Fed with our fuel, purifying Agni, so blaze to us auspiciously for glory. This prayer of our. May Varuna grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

hymns.title: HYMN XCVI. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: HE in the ancient way by strength engendered, lo! straight hath taken to himself all wisdom. The waters and the bowl have made him friendly. The Devas possessed the wealth bestowing Agni.

p: At Ayu's ancient call he by his wisdom gave all this progeny of men their being, and, by refulgent light, heaven and the waters. The Devas possessed the wealth. bestowing Agni.

p: Praise him, ye Aryan folk, as chief performer of offering adored and ever toiling, well-tended, Son of Strength, the Constant Giver. The Devas possessed the wealth bestowing Agni.

p: That Matarisvan rich in wealth and treasure., light-winner, finds a pathway for his offspring. Guard of our folk, Father of earth and heaven. The Devas possessed the wealth bestowing Agni.

p: Night and Dawn, changing each the other's colour, meeting together suckle one same Infant: Golden between the heaven and earth he shineth. The Devas possessed the wealth bestowing Agni.

p: Root of wealth, gathering-place of treasure.s, banner of offering, who grants the suppliant's wishes: Preserving him as their own life immortal, the Devas possessed the wealth-bestowing Agni.

p: Now and of old the home of wealth, the mansion of what is born and what was born aforetime, Guard of what is and what will be hereafter.the Devas possessed the wealth bestowing Agni.

p: May the Wealth-Giver grant us conquering riches. May the Wealth-Giver grant us wealth with heroes. May the Wealth-Giver grant us food with offspring, and length of day. May the Wealth-Giver send us.

p: Fed with our fuel, purifying Agni, so blaze to us auspiciously for glory. This prayer of our. May Varuna grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

hymns.title: HYMN XCVII. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: CHASING with light our sin away, O Agni, shine thou wealth on us. May his light chase our sin away.

p: For goodly fields, for pleasant homes, for wealth we offering to thee. May his light chase our sin away.

p: Best praiser of all these be he; foremost, our chiefs who offering. May his light chase our sin away.

p: So that thy worshippers and we, thine, Agni, in our son. May live. May his light chase our sin away.

p: As ever-conquering Agni's beams of splendour go to every side, may his light chase our sin away.

p: To every side thy face is turned, thou art triumphant everywhere. May his light chase our sin away.

p: O thou whose face looks every way, bear us past foes as in a ship. May his light chase our sin away.

p: As in a ship, convey thou us for our advantage o’er the flood. May his light chase our sin away.

hymns.title: HYMN XCVIII. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: STILL in Vaisvanara's grac. May we continue: yea, he is King supreme o’er all things living. Sprung hence to life upon this All he looketh. Vaisvanara hath rivalry with Surya.

p: Present in heaven, in earth, all-present Agni.all plants that grow on ground hath he pervaded. May Agni. May Vaisvanara with vigour, present, preserve us day and night from foemen.

p: Be this thy truth, Vaisvanara, to us ward: let wealth in rich abundance gather round us. This prayer of our. May Varuna grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

hymns.title: HYMN XCIX. Agni.
hymns.text: p: FOR Jatavedas let us press the Soma. May he consume the wealth of the malignant. May Agni carry us through all our troubles, through grief as in a boat across the river.

hymns.title: HYMN C. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: MAY he who hath his home with strength, the Mighty, the King supreme of earth and spacious heaven, Lord of true power, to he invoked in battles.may Indra, girt by Maruts, be our assist.

p: Whose way is unattainable like Surya's: he in each fight is the strong Vrtra conquerer, Mightiest with his Friends in his own courses. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our assist.

p: Whose paths go forth in their great might resistless, forthmilking, as it were, heaven's genial moisture. With manly strength triumphant, foe-subduer.may Indra, girt by Maruts, be our assist.

p: Among Angirases he was the chiefest, a friend with friends, mighty amid the mighty. Praiser mid praisers, honoured most of singers. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our assist.

p: Strong with the Rudras as with his own children, in manly battle conquering his foemen ' With his close comrades doing deeds of glory.may Indra, girt by Maruts, be our assist.

p: Humbler of pride, exciter of the conflict, the Lord of heroes, Deva.invoked of many, may he this day gain with our men the sunlight. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our assist.

p: His help hath made him cheerer in the battle, the folk have made him guardian of their comfort. Sole Lord is he of every holy service. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our assist.

p: To him the Hero, on high days of prowess, heroes for help and booty shall betake them. He hath found light even in the blinding darkness. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our assist.
